RN   [37]
RP   VARIANT PKD2 PRO-384.
RX   PubMed=21115670; DOI=10.1093/ndt/gfq720;
RA   Hoefele J., Mayer K., Scholz M., Klein H.G.;
RT   "Novel PKD1 and PKD2 mutations in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney
RT   disease (ADPKD).";
RL   Nephrol. Dial. Transplant. 26:2181-2188(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a cation channel involved in fluid-flow
CC       mechanosensation by the primary cilium in renal epithelium
CC       (PubMed:18695040). Functions as outward-rectifying K(+) channel,
CC       but is also permeable to Ca(2+), and to a much lesser degree also
CC       to Na(+) (PubMed:11854751, PubMed:15692563, PubMed:27071085,
CC       PubMed:27991905). May contribute to the release of Ca(2+) stores
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum (PubMed:11854751, PubMed:20881056).
CC       Together with TRPV4, forms mechano- and thermosensitive channels
CC       in cilium (PubMed:18695040). PKD1 and PKD2 may function through a
CC       common signaling pathway that is necessary to maintain the normal,
CC       differentiated state of renal tubule cells. Acts as a regulator of
CC       cilium length, together with PKD1. The dynamic control of cilium
CC       length is essential in the regulation of mechanotransductive
CC       signaling. The cilium length response creates a negative feedback
CC       loop whereby fluid shear-mediated deflection of the primary
CC       cilium, which decreases intracellular cAMP, leads to cilium
CC       shortening and thus decreases flow-induced signaling. Also
CC       involved in left-right axis specification via its role in sensing
CC       nodal flow; forms a complex with PKD1L1 in cilia to facilitate
CC       flow detection in left-right patterning. Detection of asymmetric
CC       nodal flow gives rise to a Ca(2+) signal that is required for
CC       normal, asymmetric expression of genes involved in the
CC       specification of body left-right laterality (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channnel activity is regulated by
CC       phosphorylation (PubMed:16551655, PubMed:20881056,
CC       PubMed:26269590). Channnel activity is regulated by intracellular
CC       Ca(2+) (PubMed:11854751). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:20881056, PubMed:27768895,
CC       PubMed:27991905, PubMed:28092368). Interacts with PKD1, giving
CC       rise to a complex formed by one PKD1 chain and a PKD2 homooligomer
CC       (PubMed:20881056, PubMed:19556541). In vitro results suggest
CC       assembly of a complex composed of one PKD1 chain and a PKD2
CC       trimer; the physiological significance of this is uncertain
CC       (PubMed:19556541). Isoform 1 interacts with PKD1 while isoform 3
CC       does not (By similarity). Interacts with PKD1L1. PKD1 requires the
CC       presence of PKD2 for stable expression (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with CD2AP (PubMed:10913159). Interacts with HAX1
CC       (PubMed:10760273). Interacts with NEK8 (By similarity). Part of a
CC       complex containing AKAP5, ADCY5, ADCY6 and PDE4C (By similarity).
CC       Interacts (via C-terminus) with TRPV4 (via C-terminus)
CC       (PubMed:18695040). Interacts (via C-terminal acidic region) with
CC       PACS1 and PACS2; these interactions retain the protein in the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum and prevent trafficking to the cell membrane
CC       (PubMed:15692563). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10760273, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10913159,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-7813714;
CC       O35387:Hax1 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-642449;
CC       Q02363:ID2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-713450;
CC       Q91908:itpr1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-9633447;
CC       Q6A162:KRT40; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10171697;
CC       P60410:KRTAP10-8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10171774;
CC       P43361:MAGEA8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10182930;
CC       P98161:PKD1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-1752013;
CC       P98161-3:PKD1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-15930070;
CC       O08852:Pkd1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-6666305;
CC       O15162:PLSCR1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-740019;
CC       J9P3Y7:RYR2 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-15630134;
CC       P48995:TRPC1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-929665;
CC       P48995-2:TRPC1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-9830970;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10760273, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368, ECO:0000305|PubMed:10913159}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27071085, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959}. Note=Retained in the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum by interaction with PACS1 and PACS2 (PubMed:15692563).
CC       Detected on kidney tubule basolateral membranes and basal
CC       cytoplasmic vesicles (PubMed:10770959). Cell surface and cilium
CC       localization requires GANAB (PubMed:27259053).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=delta6;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-2; Sequence=VSP_042479, VSP_042480;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=delta7;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-3; Sequence=VSP_042481;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=delta9;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-4; Sequence=VSP_042482, VSP_042483;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=delta12/13;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-5; Sequence=VSP_042484;
CC         Note=Minor isoform.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in fetal and adult kidney
CC       (PubMed:10770959). Detected at the thick ascending limb of the
CC       loop of Henle, at distal tubules, including the distal convoluted
CC       tubule and cortical collecting tubules, with weak staining of the
CC       collecting duct (PubMed:10770959). Detected on placenta
CC       syncytiotrophoblasts (at protein level) (PubMed:26269590).
CC       Strongly expressed in ovary, fetal and adult kidney, testis, and
CC       small intestine. Not detected in peripheral leukocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8650545}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain is involved in
CC       oligomerization and the interaction with PKD1 (PubMed:18694932,
CC       PubMed:19556541). The isolated coiled-coil domain forms a
CC       homotrimer in vitro; the homotrimer interacts with a single PKD1
CC       chain (PubMed:19556541). The coiled-coil domain binds calcium and
CC       undergoes a calcium-induced conformation change (in vitro)
CC       (PubMed:18694932). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18694932,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation is important for protein
CC       function; a mutant that lacks the N-terminal phosphorylation sites
CC       cannot complement a zebrafish pkd2-deficient mutant
CC       (PubMed:16551655). PKD-mediated phosphorylation at the C-terminus
CC       regulates its function in the release of Ca(2+) stores from the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum (PubMed:20881056). PKA-mediated
CC       phosphorylation at a C-terminal site strongly increases the open
CC       probability of the channel, but does not increase single channel
CC       conductance (PubMed:26269590). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. The four subunits in a tetramer probably
CC       differ in the extent of glycosylation; simultaneous glycosylation
CC       of all experimentally validated sites would probably create steric
CC       hindrance. Thus, glycosylation at Asn-305 is not compatible with
CC       glycosylation at Asn-328; only one of these two residues is
CC       glycosylated at a given time. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Polycystic kidney disease 2 (PKD2) [MIM:613095]: A
CC       disorder characterized by progressive formation and enlargement of
CC       cysts in both kidneys, typically leading to end-stage renal
CC       disease in adult life. Cysts also occurs in the liver and other
CC       organs. It represents approximately 15% of the cases of autosomal
CC       dominant polycystic kidney disease. PKD2 is clinically milder than
CC       PKD1 but it has a deleterious impact on overall life expectancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10411676, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10541293,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10835625, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11968093, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12707387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14993477, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772804,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21115670, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27071085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9326320}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The mechanisms that govern channel opening are
CC       complex and still under debate; heterologous expression of PKD2 by
CC       itself or together with PKD1 gives rise to very low or
CC       undetectable spontaneous ion channel activity, in spite of its
CC       presence at the cell membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Functional Glycomics Gateway - Glycan Binding;
CC       Note=Polycystin 2 - Not a C-type lectin;
CC       URL="http://www.functionalglycomics.org/glycomics/GBPServlet?&operationType=view&cbpId=cbp_hum_Ctlect_205";

RN   [31]
RP   VARIANTS GLU-850 DEL AND SER-2091, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS
RP   GLU-850 DEL AND SER-2091.
RX   PubMed=27218670; DOI=10.1111/chd.12371;
RA   Sutphin B.S., Boczek N.J., Barajas-Martinez H., Hu D., Ye D.,
RA   Tester D.J., Antzelevitch C., Ackerman M.J.;
RT   "Molecular and functional characterization of rare CACNA1C variants in
RT   sudden unexplained death in the young.";
RL   Congenit. Heart Dis. 11:683-692(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) mediate the
CC       entry of calcium ions into excitable cells and are also involved
CC       in a variety of calcium-dependent processes, including muscle
CC       contraction, hormone or neurotransmitter release, gene expression,
CC       cell motility, cell division and cell death. The isoform alpha-1C
CC       gives rise to L-type calcium currents. Long-lasting (L-type)
CC       calcium channels belong to the 'high-voltage activated' (HVA)
CC       group. They are blocked by dihydropyridines (DHP),
CC       phenylalkylamines, benzothiazepines, and by omega-agatoxin-IIIA
CC       (omega-Aga-IIIA). They are however insensitive to omega-conotoxin-
CC       GVIA (omega-CTx-GVIA) and omega-agatoxin-IVA (omega-Aga-IVA).
CC       Calcium channels containing the alpha-1C subunit play an important
CC       role in excitation-contraction coupling in the heart. The various
CC       isoforms display marked differences in the sensitivity to DHP
CC       compounds. Binding of calmodulin or CABP1 at the same regulatory
CC       sites results in an opposit effects on the channel function.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12176756, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17071743,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7737988, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8392192,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9607315}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Voltage-dependent calcium channels are multisubunit
CC       complexes, consisting of alpha-1, alpha-2, beta and delta subunits
CC       in a 1:1:1:1 ratio. The channel activity is directed by the pore-
CC       forming and voltage-sensitive alpha-1 subunit. In many cases, this
CC       subunit is sufficient to generate voltage-sensitive calcium
CC       channel activity. The auxiliary subunits beta and alpha-2/delta
CC       linked by a disulfide bridge regulate the channel activity.
CC       Interacts with CACNA2D4. Interacts (via the N-terminus and the C-
CC       terminal C and IQ motifs) with CABP1. The binding via the C motif
CC       is calcium independent whereas the binding via IQ requires the
CC       presence of calcium and is mutually exclusive with calmodulin
CC       binding. The binding to the cytoplasmic N-terminal domain is
CC       calcium independent but is essential for the channel modulation.
CC       Interacts (via C-terminal CDB motif) with CABP5; in a calcium-
CC       dependent manner (By similarity). Interacts with CIB1; the
CC       interaction increases upon cardiomyocytes hypertrophy (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12181424,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15140941, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15141227,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15980432}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9NZU7:CABP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-907894;
CC       Q9NZU7-2:CABP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15896749, EBI-15896740;
CC       Q02641-1:CACNB1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-15707950;
CC       Q08289-1:CACNB2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-15707999;
CC       P54284:CACNB3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-1184651;
CC       P62158:CALM3; NbExp=21; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-397435;
CC       P62161:Calm3 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1038838, EBI-397530;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381}. Cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381}. Note=The interaction
CC       between RRAD and CACNB2 regulates its trafficking to the cell
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=37;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist. Exons 8A, 21, 22, 31,
CC         32, 33, 40B, 43A, 41A and 45 are alternatively spliced in a
CC         variety of combinations. Experimental confirmation may be
CC         lacking for some isoforms.;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=HFCC, Fibroblast;
CC         IsoId=Q13936-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q13936-2; Sequence=VSP_000894;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q13936-3; Sequence=VSP_000886;
CC         Note=Contains exon 8a.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q13936-4; Sequence=VSP_000887;
CC         Note=Lacks exon 21.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q13936-5; Sequence=VSP_000888;
CC         Note=Lacks exon 22.;

CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in brain, heart, jejunum, ovary,
CC       pancreatic beta-cells and vascular smooth muscle. Overall
CC       expression is reduced in atherosclerotic vascular smooth muscle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12176756, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17071743,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8392192}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the four internal repeats contains five
CC       hydrophobic transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one
CC       positively charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments
CC       probably represent the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a
CC       series of positively charged amino acids at every third position.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Binding of intracellular calcium through the EF-hand motif
CC       inhibits the opening of the channel.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation by PKA activates the channel.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15381}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Timothy syndrome (TS) [MIM:601005]: Disorder
CC       characterized by multiorgan dysfunction including lethal
CC       arrhythmias, webbing of fingers and toes, congenital heart
CC       disease, immune deficiency, intermittent hypoglycemia, cognitive
CC       abnormalities and autism. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15454078,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15863612, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24728418,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25260352, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25633834,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26253506}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Brugada syndrome 3 (BRGDA3) [MIM:611875]: A heart disease
CC       characterized by the association of Brugada syndrome with
CC       shortened QT intervals. Brugada syndrome is a tachyarrhythmia
CC       characterized by right bundle branch block and ST segment
CC       elevation on an electrocardiogram (ECG). It can cause the
CC       ventricles to beat so fast that the blood is prevented from
CC       circulating efficiently in the body. When this situation occurs,
CC       the individual will faint and may die in a few minutes if the
CC       heart is not reset. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17224476}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. CACNA1C subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA02500.2; Type=Frameshift; Positions=1844; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   INVOLVEMENT IN GLSP, VARIANTS GLSP LEU-2601 AND LYS-2611 DEL,
RP   CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANT GLSP LYS-2611 DEL, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27108797; DOI=10.1016/j.ajhg.2016.03.004;
RA   Gerber S., Alzayady K.J., Burglen L., Bremond-Gignac D., Marchesin V.,

RN   [26]
RP   INVOLVEMENT IN GLSP, VARIANTS GLSP GLN-2109; ARG-2554 AND LYS-2611
RP   DEL, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=27108798; DOI=10.1016/j.ajhg.2016.03.018;
RG   DDD Study;
RA   McEntagart M., Williamson K.A., Rainger J.K., Wheeler A.,
RA   Seawright A., De Baere E., Verdin H., Bergendahl L.T., Quigley A.,
RA   Rainger J., Dixit A., Sarkar A., Lopez Laso E., Sanchez-Carpintero R.,
RA   Barrio J., Bitoun P., Prescott T., Riise R., McKee S., Cook J.,
RA   McKie L., Ceulemans B., Meire F., Temple I.K., Prieur F., Williams J.,
RA   Clouston P., Nemeth A.H., Banka S., Bengani H., Handley M., Freyer E.,
RA   Ross A., van Heyningen V., Marsh J.A., Elmslie F., FitzPatrick D.R.;
RT   "A restricted repertoire of de novo mutations in ITPR1 cause Gillespie
RT   syndrome with evidence for dominant-negative effect.";
RL   Am. J. Hum. Genet. 98:981-992(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Intracellular channel that mediates calcium release from
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum following stimulation by inositol 1,4,5-
CC       trisphosphate (PubMed:27108797). Involved in the regulation of
CC       epithelial secretion of electrolytes and fluid through the
CC       interaction with AHCYL1 (By similarity). Plays a role in ER
CC       stress-induced apoptosis. Cytoplasmic calcium released from the ER
CC       triggers apoptosis by the activation of CaM kinase II, eventually
CC       leading to the activation of downstream apoptosis pathways (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11881,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27108797}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Interacts with TRPC4. The PPXXF motif binds
CC       HOM1, HOM2 and HOM3. Interacts with RYR1, RYR2, ITPR1, SHANK1 and
CC       SHANK3. Interacts with ERP44 in a pH-, redox state- and calcium-
CC       dependent manner which results in the inhibition the calcium
CC       channel activity. The strength of this interaction inversely
CC       correlates with calcium concentration. Part of cGMP kinase
CC       signaling complex at least composed of ACTA2/alpha-actin,
CC       CNN1/calponin H1, PLN/phospholamban, PRKG1 and ITPR1. Interacts
CC       with MRVI1 and CABP1 (via N-terminus). Interacts with TESPA1.
CC       Interacts (when not phosphorylated) with AHCYL1 (when
CC       phosphorylated); the interaction suppresses inositol 1,4,5-
CC       trisphosphate binding to ITPR1 (PubMed:16793548). Interacts with
CC       AHCYL2 (with lower affinity than with AHCYL1) (PubMed:19220705).
CC       Interacts with BOK (via BH4 domain); protects ITPR1 from
CC       proteolysis by CASP3 during apoptosis (PubMed:23884412).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032348, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14685260,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15652484, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16793548,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16990611, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19220705,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23650607, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884412}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P31749:AKT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-465548, EBI-296087;
CC       P21796:VDAC1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-465548, EBI-354158;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:27108798}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, secretory vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9TU34}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Cytoplasm, perinuclear region
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27108798}. Note=Endoplasmic reticulum and
CC       secretory granules (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9TU34}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=8;
CC         Comment=There is a combination of three alternatively spliced
CC         domains at site SI, SIII and site SII (A and C). Experimental
CC         confirmation may be lacking for some isoforms.;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=SISIIISIIAC;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=SI-SIIISIIAC;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-2; Sequence=VSP_002687;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=SISIII-SII;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-3; Sequence=VSP_002688, VSP_002689, VSP_002690;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=SI-SIII-SII;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-4; Sequence=VSP_002687, VSP_002688, VSP_002689,
CC                                  VSP_002690;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=SI-SIII-SIIAC;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-5; Sequence=VSP_002687, VSP_002688;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=SISIIISIIA;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-6; Sequence=VSP_002690;
CC       Name=7; Synonyms=SI-SIII-SIIA;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-7; Sequence=VSP_002687, VSP_002690;
CC       Name=8; Synonyms=SI-SIII-SIIA;
CC         IsoId=Q14643-8; Sequence=VSP_002687, VSP_002688, VSP_002690;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The receptor contains a calcium channel in its C-terminal
CC       extremity. Its large N-terminal cytoplasmic region has the ligand-
CC       binding site in the N-terminus and modulatory sites in the middle
CC       portion immediately upstream of the channel region.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7852357}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitination at multiple lysines targets ITPR1 for
CC       proteasomal degradation. Approximately 40% of the ITPR1-associated
CC       ubiquitin is monoubiquitin, and polyubiquitins are both 'Lys-
CC       48'- and 'Lys-63'-linked (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P29994}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by cAMP kinase (PKA). Phosphorylation prevents
CC       the ligand-induced opening of the calcium channels.
CC       Phosphorylation by PKA increases the interaction with inositol
CC       1,4,5-trisphosphate and decreases the interaction with AHCYL1.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11881}.
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylated by ZDHHC6 in immune cells, leading to regulate
CC       ITPR1 stability and function. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11881}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spinocerebellar ataxia 15 (SCA15) [MIM:606658]:
CC       Spinocerebellar ataxia is a clinically and genetically
CC       heterogeneous group of cerebellar disorders. Patients show
CC       progressive incoordination of gait and often poor coordination of
CC       hands, speech and eye movements, due to degeneration of the
CC       cerebellum with variable involvement of the brainstem and spinal
CC       cord. SCA15 is an autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia (ADCA). It
CC       is very slow progressing form with a wide range of onset, ranging
CC       from childhood to adult. Most patients remain ambulatory.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17590087, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18579805}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spinocerebellar ataxia 29 (SCA29) [MIM:117360]: An
CC       autosomal dominant, congenital spinocerebellar ataxia
CC       characterized by early motor delay, hypotonia and mild cognitive
CC       delay. Affected individuals develop a very slowly progressive or
CC       non-progressive gait and limb ataxia associated with cerebellar
CC       atrophy on brain imaging. Additional variable features include
CC       nystagmus, dysarthria, and tremor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22986007,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26770814}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Gillespie syndrome (GLSP) [MIM:206700]: A rare disease
CC       characterized by bilateral iris hypoplasia, congenital hypotonia,
CC       non-progressive ataxia, progressive cerebellar atrophy, and mental
CC       retardation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27108797,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27108798}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Calcium appears to inhibit ligand binding to the
CC       receptor, most probably by interacting with a distinct calcium-
CC       binding protein which then inhibits the receptor.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Alternative splice sites (AA 1053-1054) represent a non-
CC       canonical GA-AG donor-acceptor pair, but are well-supported by all
CC       available human transcripts, and by homologous transcripts in
CC       mouse, rat and cow. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHENOTYPE, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ASP-125.
RX   PubMed=23884934; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5919-12.2013;
RA   Tanis J.E., Ma Z., Krajacic P., He L., Foskett J.K., Lamitina T.;
RT   "CLHM-1 is a functionally conserved and conditionally toxic Ca2+-
RT   permeable ion channel in Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 33:12275-12286(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming subunit of a voltage-gated ion channel.
CC       Permeable to monovalent cations, divalent cations and anions with
CC       selectivity Ca(2+) > Mg(2+) > Na(+) = K(+) > Cl(-). Acts both as a
CC       voltage-gated and calcium-activated ion channel. Required for
CC       normal locomotion. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884934}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884934};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in head and body wall muscles, IL2,
CC       ASG, ASI, ASJ, PHA and PHB sensory neurons, and spermatheca.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884934}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Uncoordinated locomotion with mutants
CC       showing reduced forward velocity, muscle force and power
CC       production. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884934}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CALHM family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria. Constitutes a pore-
CC       forming and calcium-conducting subunit. Mitochondrial calcium
CC       homeostasis plays key roles in cellular physiology and regulates
CC       cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium signals and activation of
CC       cell death pathways. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.

DE            Short=cMCU {ECO:0000303|PubMed:27135929};

GN   Name=mcu-1 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:25313960,
GN   ECO:0000312|WormBase:K02B2.3};

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;
RX   PubMed=9851916; DOI=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012;
RG   The C. elegans sequencing consortium;

RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=25313960; DOI=10.1016/j.devcel.2014.08.002;
RA   Xu S., Chisholm A.D.;
RT   "C. elegans epidermal wounding induces a mitochondrial ROS burst that
RT   promotes wound repair.";
RL   Dev. Cell 31:48-60(2014).
RN   [3] {ECO:0000312|PDB:5ID3}
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 167-317 OF MUTANT ALA-238, ENZYME REGULATION,
RP   SUBUNIT, DOMAIN, AND MUTAGENESIS OF SER-238.
RX   PubMed=27135929; DOI=10.1038/nature17656;
RA   Oxenoid K., Dong Y., Cao C., Cui T., Sancak Y., Markhard A.L.,
RA   Grabarek Z., Kong L., Liu Z., Ouyang B., Cong Y., Mootha V.K.,
RA   Chou J.J.;
RT   "Architecture of the mitochondrial calcium uniporter.";
RL   Nature 533:269-273(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria (PubMed:25313960).
CC       Constitutes a pore-forming and calcium-conducting subunit (By
CC       similarity). Mitochondrial calcium homeostasis plays key roles in
CC       cellular physiology and regulates cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic
CC       calcium signals and activation of cell death pathways (By
CC       similarity). Required for rapid mitochondrial calcium uptake and
CC       mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) production after
CC       wounding (PubMed:25313960). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25313960}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by ruthenium red or its derivative
CC       Ru360; possibly by obstructing the pore.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135929}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-11465987, EBI-11465987;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Forms a well-packed pentamer with an overall cylindrical
CC       shape. The inner core of the pentamer is formed with the second
CC       transmembrane region and the second coiled-coil region (residues
CC       293-316): while the transmembrane regions pack into a five-helix
CC       bundle having a largely polar pore across the membrane, the
CC       coiled-coil outside the membrane forms a pentamer with a
CC       hydrophobic core, which may contribute to stabilizing the
CC       transmembrane pore structure. The transmembrane pore is wrapped by
CC       the first transmembrane region through contacts between the first
CC       and the second transmembrane regions. The second transmembrane is
CC       followed by the inner juxtamembrane region (IJMH) that orients at
CC       a wide angle relative to the second transmembrane. The two core
CC       domains are held together on the periphery by the outer
CC       juxtamembrane helix (OJMH), which contains a kink around Glu-204
CC       and interacts with the IJMH. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135929}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The critical DXXE motif connecting the transmembrane
CC       regions forms a pentameric barrel that constitutes the mouth of
CC       the pore. Inside the barrel, both acidic residues are in position
CC       to form two carboxylate rings: the Asp-240 ring is solvent
CC       exposed, and the Glu-243 ring is located deeper, guarding the
CC       entrance of the second transmembrane pore. In absence of emre-1
CC       regulator, the calcium ions cannot exit the channel, suggesting
CC       that emre-1-binding induces conformational rearrangements to allow
CC       calcium to exit. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135929}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: null mutants are viable and fertile but show
CC       strongly impaired mitochondrial calcium following laser or needle
CC       wounding. Reduced wound-induced mitoflashes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25313960}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MCU (TC 1.A.77) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RN   [7]
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF CYS-629.
RX   PubMed=9539432;
RA   Eberl D.F., Ren D., Feng G., Lorenz L.J., van Vactor D., Hall L.M.;
RT   "Genetic and developmental characterization of Dmca1D, a calcium
RT   channel alpha-1 subunit gene in Drosophila melanogaster.";
RL   Genetics 148:1159-1169(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) mediate the
CC       entry of calcium ions into excitable cells and are also involved
CC       in a variety of calcium-dependent processes, including muscle
CC       contraction, hormone or neurotransmitter release, gene expression,
CC       cell motility, cell division and cell death. Encodes a
CC       dihydropyridine- and diltiazem-sensitive current in larval body
CC       wall muscle. Vital for embryonic development.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7869089}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=A;
CC         IsoId=Q24270-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B;
CC         IsoId=Q24270-3; Sequence=VSP_017568;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=C;
CC         IsoId=Q24270-4; Sequence=VSP_017569;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=D;
CC         IsoId=Q24270-2; Sequence=VSP_007604, VSP_007605;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the adult body, head and leg.
CC       Highly expressed in the embryonic nervous system.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Faintly expressed in embryos at 9-12 hours.
CC       Expression increases rapidly as the nervous system matures,
CC       peaking just prior to hatching. A second peak is observed in late
CC       pupal stages around 73-108 hours postpuparium.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the four internal repeats contains five
CC       hydrophobic transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one
CC       positively charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments
CC       probably represent the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a
CC       series of positively charged amino acids at every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1, Met-494, Met-539, Met-544
CC       or Met-553 is the initiator. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAL13497.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE OF 4619-5127, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, AND TISSUE
RP   SPECIFICITY.
RC   TISSUE=Brain {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1338312};
RX   PubMed=1338312;
RA   Hasan G., Rosbash M.;

RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=10811919; DOI=10.1073/pnas.110145997;
RA   Sullivan K.M.C., Scott K., Zuker C.S., Rubin G.M.;
RT   "The ryanodine receptor is essential for larval development in
RT   Drosophila melanogaster.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 97:5942-5947(2000).
RN   [6]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-1459, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Embryo;
RX   PubMed=18327897; DOI=10.1021/pr700696a;
RA   Zhai B., Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Mintseris J., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Phosphoproteome analysis of Drosophila melanogaster embryos.";
RL   J. Proteome Res. 7:1675-1682(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Intracellular calcium channel that is required for
CC       proper muscle function during embryonic development and may be
CC       essential for excitation-contraction coupling in larval body wall
CC       muscles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10811919,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=The
CC       number of predicted transmembrane domains varies between
CC       orthologs, but both N-terminus and C-terminus seem to be
CC       cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=A {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-2; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-3; Sequence=VSP_050196;
CC       Name=C {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-4; Sequence=VSP_050195;
CC       Name=D {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-5; Sequence=VSP_050195, VSP_050196;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: During embryonic stages 9-10, expression is
CC       seen in mesoderm of all segments in progenitors of the cephalic
CC       and somatic muscles. Adults exhibit high expression in tubular
CC       'jump' muscles of thorax and leg, and lower expression in the
CC       brain, ventral ganglion, head muscles and proboscis muscles.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10811919, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1338312,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Abundant in 6-12 hours embryos, reduced
CC       expression in second and third instar larval stages and adults.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1338312, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open Ca-release channel with high
CC       affinity and maintains the channel in an open conformation. The
CC       calcium release channel is modulated by calcium ions, magnesium
CC       ions, ATP and calmodulin (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

ID   CAC1M_MUSDO             Reviewed;        1687 AA.
AC   Q25452;
DT   15-JUL-1999, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-NOV-1996, sequence version 1.
DT   27-SEP-2017, entry version 90.
DE   RecName: Full=Muscle calcium channel subunit alpha-1;
DE   AltName: Full=MDL-alpha-1;
OS   Musca domestica (House fly).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Hexapoda; Insecta;
OC   Pterygota; Neoptera; Holometabola; Diptera; Brachycera; Muscomorpha;
OC   Muscoidea; Muscidae; Musca.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=7370;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Muscle;
RX   PubMed=8313972; DOI=10.1016/0014-5793(94)80413-3;
RA   Grabner M., Bachmann A., Rosenthal F., Striessnig J., Schultz C.,
RA   Tautz D., Glossmann H.;
RT   "Insect calcium channels. Molecular cloning of an alpha 1-subunit from
RT   housefly (Musca domestica) muscle.";
RL   FEBS Lett. 339:189-194(1994).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) mediate the
CC       entry of calcium ions into excitable cells and are also involved
CC       in a variety of calcium-dependent processes, including muscle
CC       contraction, hormone or neurotransmitter release, gene expression,
CC       cell motility, cell division and cell death (By similarity). MDL-
CC       alpha1 encodes a dihydropyridine- and diltiazem-sensitive current
CC       in larval body wall muscle. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in the larval body
CC       wall musculature. In adults, highest expression in thorax followed
CC       by head and at a lower extent by abdomen.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Late embryonic.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the four internal repeats contains five
CC       hydrophobic transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one
CC       positively charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments
CC       probably represent the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a
CC       series of positively charged amino acids at every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION, ENZYME REGULATION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=24889638; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1400514111;
RA   Kovacs-Bogdan E., Sancak Y., Kamer K.J., Plovanich M., Jambhekar A.,
RA   Huber R.J., Myre M.A., Blower M.D., Mootha V.K.;
RT   "Reconstitution of the mitochondrial calcium uniporter in yeast.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:8985-8990(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria (PubMed:24889638).
CC       Constitutes a pore-forming and calcium-conducting subunit
CC       (PubMed:24889638). Mitochondrial calcium homeostasis plays key
CC       roles in cellular physiology and regulates cell bioenergetics,
CC       cytoplasmic calcium signals and activation of cell death pathways.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24889638}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by ruthenium red or its derivative
CC       Ru360. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24889638}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24889638}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24889638}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Forms a well-packed pentamer with an overall cylindrical
CC       shape. The inner core of the pentamer is formed with the second
CC       transmembrane region and the second coiled-coil region: while the
CC       transmembrane regions pack into a five-helix bundle having a
CC       largely polar pore across the membrane, the coiled-coil outside
CC       the membrane forms a pentamer with a hydrophobic core. The inner
CC       core is wrapped by the first transmembrane region through contacts
CC       between the first and the second transmembrane regions. The second
CC       transmembrane is followed by the inner juxtamembrane region (IJMH)
CC       that orients at a wide angle relative to the second transmembrane.
CC       The two core domains are held together on the periphery by the
CC       outer juxtamembrane helix (OJMH). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The critical DXXE motif connecting the transmembrane
CC       regions forms a pentameric barrel that constitutes the mouth of
CC       the pore. Inside the barrel, two acidic residues are in position
CC       to form two carboxylate rings. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MCU (TC 1.A.77) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   INDUCTION, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21457451; DOI=10.1111/j.1567-1364.2011.00730.x;
RA   Wang H., Liang Y., Zhang B., Zheng W., Xing L., Li M.;
RT   "Alkaline stress triggers an immediate calcium fluctuation in Candida
RT   albicans mediated by Rim101p and Crz1p transcription factors.";
RL   FEMS Yeast Res. 11:430-439(2011).
RN   [5]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=25308698; DOI=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2014.09.011;
RA   Yu Q., Zhang B., Yang B., Chen J., Wang H., Jia C., Ding X., Xu N.,
RA   Dong Y., Zhang B., Xing L., Li M.;
RT   "Interaction between the vacuole, the mitochondria and oxidative
RT   stress response is governed by the transient receptor potential
RT   channel in Candida albicans.";
RL   Free Radic. Biol. Med. 77:152-167(2014).
RN   [6]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=24368068; DOI=10.1016/j.ijmm.2013.11.022;
RA   Yu Q., Wang F., Zhao Q., Chen J., Zhang B., Ding X., Wang H., Yang B.,
RA   Lu G., Zhang B., Li M.;
RT   "A novel role of the vacuolar calcium channel Yvc1 in stress response,
RT   morphogenesis and pathogenicity of Candida albicans.";
RL   Int. J. Med. Microbiol. 304:339-350(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Vacuolar calcium channel involved in the release of
CC       calcium ions from the vacuole in response to hyperosmotic or
CC       alkaline stress. Required for activation of CAP1-related
CC       transcription of oxidative stress response (OSR) genes, but also
CC       for maintaining the stability of both the mitochondria and the
CC       vacuole in a potassium- and calcium-dependent manner. Contributes
CC       to pathogenicity. Plays a key role in hyphal polarized growth and
CC       re-orientation to host-signals through its contribution to the
CC       localization of the Spitzenkoerper to the hyphal tips.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21457451, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368068,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25308698}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368068}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is down-regulated in response to alkaline pH
CC       when CRZ1 or RIM101 are deleted. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21457451}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Leads to hypersensitivity to oxidative
CC       stress, increased sensitivity to killing by macrophages, reduced
CC       ability to invade epithelium cells, and attenuated virulence in a
CC       mouse model. Shows defects in hyphal maintenance, hyphal growth
CC       and flocculation. Prevents the localization of the Spitzenkoerper
CC       to hyphal tips. Enhances mitochondrial depolarization and
CC       apoptosis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368068,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25308698}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

DE   AltName: Full=Protein orai-1;
DE   AltName: Full=Transmembrane protein 142A;
GN   Name=Orai1; Synonyms=Cracm1, Tmem142a;
OS   Rattus norvegicus (Rat).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Glires; Rodentia; Myomorpha;

OX   NCBI_TaxID=10116;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [2]
RP   INTERACTION WITH CALM.
RX   PubMed=23109337; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M112.380964;
RA   Liu Y., Zheng X., Mueller G.A., Sobhany M., DeRose E.F., Zhang Y.,
RA   London R.E., Birnbaumer L.;
RT   "Crystal structure of calmodulin binding domain of orai1 in complex
RT   with Ca2+ calmodulin displays a unique binding mode.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 287:43030-43041(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ca(2+) release-activated Ca(2+) (CRAC) channel subunit
CC       which mediates Ca(2+) influx following depletion of intracellular
CC       Ca(2+) stores and channel activation by the Ca(2+) sensor, STIM1.
CC       CRAC channels are the main pathway for Ca(2+) influx in T-cells
CC       and promote the immune response to pathogens by activating the
CC       transcription factor NFAT. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with STIM1 and STIM2; this regulates channel
CC       activity (By similarity). Interacts with CALM; this may displace
CC       STIM1 and STIM2 and might thereby modulate channel activity
CC       (PubMed:23109337). Interacts with CRACR2A/EFCAB4B; the interaction
CC       is direct and takes place in absence of Ca(2+) (By similarity).
CC       Forms a complex with CRACR2A/EFCAB4B and STIM1 at low
CC       concentration of Ca(2+), the complex dissociates at elevated
CC       Ca(2+) concentrations (By similarity). Interacts with SLC35G1 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with UBQLN1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23109337}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       D4A5X1:Stim2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-9700451, EBI-9700435;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, autophagosome
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}. Note=Colocalizes with UBQLN1 in
CC       the autophagosome. Colocalizes with STIM1 at the cell membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}.
CC   -!- PTM: Cys-196 is oxidated, leading to inactivate channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96D31}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Orai family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-814, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Lung;
RX   PubMed=21183079; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2010.12.001;
RA   Huttlin E.L., Jedrychowski M.P., Elias J.E., Goswami T., Rad R.,
RA   Beausoleil S.A., Villen J., Haas W., Sowa M.E., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "A tissue-specific atlas of mouse protein phosphorylation and
RT   expression.";
RL   Cell 143:1174-1189(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thought to form a receptor-activated non-selective
CC       calcium permeant cation channel. Probably is operated by a
CC       phosphatidylinositol second messenger system activated by receptor
CC       tyrosine kinases or G-protein coupled receptors. Activated by
CC       diacylglycerol (DAG) in a membrane-delimited fashion,
CC       independently of protein kinase C. Seems not to be activated by
CC       intracellular calcium store depletion.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Y210}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer; forms channel complex. Interacts with MX1 and
CC       RNF24. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Y210}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q96D31:ORAI1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15563578, EBI-2291476;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Y210}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Y210}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Lung and brain.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by FYN, leading to an increase of TRPC6
CC       channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14761972}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. TRPC6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Huttlin E.L., Jedrychowski M.P., Elias J.E., Goswami T., Rad R.,
RA   Beausoleil S.A., Villen J., Haas W., Sowa M.E., Gygi S.P.;

RL   Cell 143:1174-1189(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) mediate the
CC       entry of calcium ions into excitable cells and are also involved
CC       in a variety of calcium-dependent processes, including muscle
CC       contraction, hormone or neurotransmitter release, gene expression,
CC       cell motility, cell division and cell death. The isoform alpha-1E
CC       gives rise to R-type calcium currents. R-type calcium channels
CC       belong to the 'high-voltage activated' (HVA) group and are blocked
CC       by nickel, and partially by omega-agatoxin-IIIA (omega-Aga-IIIA).
CC       They are however insensitive to dihydropyridines (DHP), omega-
CC       conotoxin-GVIA (omega-CTx-GVIA), and omega-agatoxin-IVA (omega-
CC       Aga-IVA). Calcium channels containing alpha-1E subunit could be
CC       involved in the modulation of firing patterns of neurons which is
CC       important for information processing.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with EFHC1. Voltage-dependent calcium channels
CC       are multisubunit complexes, consisting of alpha-1, alpha-2, beta
CC       and delta subunits in a 1:1:1:1 ratio. The channel activity is
CC       directed by the pore-forming and voltage-sensitive alpha-1
CC       subunit. In many cases, this subunit is sufficient to generate
CC       voltage-sensitive calcium channel activity. The auxiliary subunits
CC       beta and alpha-2/delta linked by a disulfide bridge regulate the
CC       channel activity.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in neuronal tissues, retina, spleen,
CC       and pancreatic islet cells.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the four internal repeats contains five
CC       hydrophobic transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one
CC       positively charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments
CC       probably represent the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a
CC       series of positively charged amino acids at every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. CACNA1E subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate, a second
CC       messenger that mediates the release of intracellular calcium.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Interacts with TRPC1, TRPC3, TRPC4.
CC       Interacts with TRPV4 (By similarity). Interacts with SIGMAR1
CC       (PubMed:11149946). Interacts with AKT1 and PML. Interacts with
CC       LRMP (via coiled-coil domain) (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       CABP1 (PubMed:12032348). Interacts with TMBIM4/LFG4 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with CEMIP (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       TESPA1 (By similarity). Interacts with TMEM203 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with BOK; regulates ITPR3 expression (PubMed:23884412).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P70227, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11149946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032348,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884412}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The receptor contains a calcium channel in its C-terminal
CC       extremity. Its large N-terminal cytoplasmic region has the ligand-
CC       binding site in the N-terminus and modulatory sites in the middle
CC       portion immediately upstream of the channel region.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues. Phosphorylated by AKT1
CC       on serine and/or threonine residues (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27212239; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2016.04.051;
RA   Wang Q.C., Zheng Q., Tan H., Zhang B., Li X., Yang Y., Yu J., Liu Y.,
RA   Chai H., Wang X., Sun Z., Wang J.Q., Zhu S., Wang F., Yang M., Guo C.,
RA   Wang H., Zheng Q., Li Y., Chen Q., Zhou A., Tang T.S.;
RT   "TMCO1 is an ER Ca(2+) load-activated Ca(2+) channel.";
RL   Cell 165:1454-1466(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-selective channel required to prevent calcium
CC       stores from overfilling, thereby playing a key role in calcium
CC       homeostasis (PubMed:27212239). In response to endoplasmic
CC       reticulum overloading, assembles into a homotetramer, forming a
CC       functional calcium-selective channel, regulating the calcium
CC       content in endoplasmic reticulum store (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00, ECO:0000305|PubMed:27212239}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer and homotetramer. Homodimer under resting
CC       conditions; forms homotetramers following and endoplasmic
CC       reticulum calcium overload. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}. Note=The first transmembrane
CC       region is required for localization to the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UM00}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q6DGW9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q6DGW9-2; Sequence=VSP_058496;
CC         Note=Ref.2 (AAH92873/AAI64974) sequences are in conflict in
CC         position: 9:A->S. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMCO1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [8]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=26432887; DOI=10.1242/bio.014076;
RA   Roxo-Rosa M., Jacinto R., Sampaio P., Lopes S.S.;
RT   "The zebrafish Kupffer's vesicle as a model system for the molecular
RT   mechanisms by which the lack of Polycystin-2 leads to stimulation of
RT   CFTR.";
RL   Biol. Open 4:1356-1366(2015).
RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=25660539; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2014.12.051;
RA   Yuan S., Zhao L., Brueckner M., Sun Z.;
RT   "Intraciliary calcium oscillations initiate vertebrate left-right
RT   asymmetry.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 25:556-567(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as non-selective cation channel (By
CC       similarity). Required for normal oscillation of Ca(2+) levels
CC       within cilia; these oscillations of the intraciliary Ca(2+) levels
CC       can trigger cytoplasmic Ca(2+) signaling cascades
CC       (PubMed:25660539). May contribute to the release of Ca(2+) stores
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum (By similarity). Required for
CC       normal temporal variation of the intracellular Ca(2+) levels in
CC       the heart (PubMed:23376035). Plays a role in fluid-flow
CC       mechanosensation (By similarity). Required for normal
CC       specification of the body left-right axis during embryogenesis,
CC       most likely via its role in ciliary Ca(2+) oscillations in
CC       Kupffer's vesicle (PubMed:15269167, PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:16943304, PubMed:17360770, PubMed:23376035,
CC       PubMed:25660539). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15269167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25660539}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channnel activity is regulated by
CC       phosphorylation. Channnel activity is regulated by intracellular
CC       Ca(2+). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (By similarity). Interacts with pkd1l1 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:H2LRU7,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Cell membrane, sarcolemma
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Cytoplasm, myofibril, sarcomere
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035}. Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26432887}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Cell projection, cilium
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC       Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, cilium basal body
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Note=Detected at the basolateral
CC       cell membrane and on apical, lumenal cilia in anterior, proximal
CC       pronephric ducts, and in intracellular vesicles in the posterior
CC       part of the pronephric duct. Detected on apical cell membranes on
CC       epithelial cells in the ear. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected along cilia and at the cilium basal
CC       body in Kupffer's vesicle at the 10 somite stage
CC       (PubMed:26432887). Detected in heart at 48hpf (PubMed:23376035).
CC       Detected in muscle and pronephric kidney at 48 hpf
CC       (PubMed:16943304). Detected on trunk muscle sarcolemma and
CC       sarcomere, on ependymal cell cilia in brain, at the apical cell
CC       membrane in epithelial cells in the ear, at the lateral line organ
CC       and olfactory placode at 56 hpf (PubMed:16943304). Detected in
CC       adult kidney (at protein level) (PubMed:16943304).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: First detected at the onset of gastrulation
CC       in a band at the blastoderm margin (PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:17360770). Ubiquitous during gastrulation, somatogenesis
CC       and at 48 hpf (PubMed:16943304). During gastrulation, detected at
CC       the hypoblast of the dorsal midline and in dorsal forerunner cells
CC       that form a ciliated Kupffer's vesicle later on (PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:17360770, PubMed:26432887). Ubiquitous during early somite
CC       stages, with high levels of expression in Kupffer's vesicle
CC       (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:17360770). At subsequent stages, detected
CC       in pronephric duct primordia and neural floorplate
CC       (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:16943304, PubMed:17360770,
CC       PubMed:26432887). Highly expressed in brain at 24 hpf
CC       (PubMed:16216239). At 3 dpf, detected at pharyngeal arches and the
CC       pectoral fin bud (PubMed:16216239). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain is involved in
CC       oligomerization. The coiled-coil domain binds calcium and
CC       undergoes a calcium-induced conformation change (in vitro).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation is important for protein
CC       function; a mutant human construct that lacks the N-terminal
CC       phosphorylation sites cannot complement a zebrafish pkd2-deficient
CC       mutant. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. The four subunits in a tetramer probably
CC       differ in the extent of glycosylation; simultaneous glycosylation
CC       of all experimentally validated sites would probably create steric
CC       hindrance. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Morpholino knockdown of the protein impairs
CC       specification of the left-right axis during embryonic development
CC       and randomization of heart and gut looping, plus misexpression of
CC       left-side specific genes (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:16943304,
CC       PubMed:17360770, PubMed:26432887, PubMed:25660539). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein causes body curvature, tail curling,
CC       hydrocephalus and kidney cysts (PubMed:15269167, PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:16943304, PubMed:16551655, PubMed:17360770,
CC       PubMed:23376035, PubMed:26432887). Morpholino knockdown has no
CC       effect on number, length or motility of pronephric cilia, but the
CC       fluid flow through the pronephric ducts seems to be impaired due
CC       to physical obstruction of the ducts (PubMed:16943304). Likewise,
CC       morpholino knockdown of the protein has no effect on the motility
CC       of cilia in Kupffer's vesicle (PubMed:25660539). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein leads to an increase of the volume of
CC       Kupffer's vesicle, without any change in the proliferation of the
CC       cells that line the vesicle (PubMed:26432887). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein leads to impaired heart function,
CC       characterized by arrhytmia and frequently associated with
CC       pericardial and abdominal edema and atrioventricular block
CC       (PubMed:23376035). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15269167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.

RL   J. Neurosci. 26:8748-8757(2006).
RN   [15]
RP   INVOLVEMENT IN DU.
RX   PubMed=17135419; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3080-06.2006;
RA   Donato R., Page K.M., Koch D., Nieto-Rostro M., Foucault I.,
RA   Davies A., Wilkinson T., Rees M., Edwards F.A., Dolphin A.C.;
RT   "The ducky(2J) mutation in Cacna2d2 results in reduced spontaneous
RT   Purkinje cell activity and altered gene expression.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 26:12576-12586(2006).
RN   [16]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Brain, and Heart;
RX   PubMed=21183079; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2010.12.001;
RA   Huttlin E.L., Jedrychowski M.P., Elias J.E., Goswami T., Rad R.,
RA   Beausoleil S.A., Villen J., Haas W., Sowa M.E., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "A tissue-specific atlas of mouse protein phosphorylation and
RT   expression.";
RL   Cell 143:1174-1189(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The alpha-2/delta subunit of voltage-dependent calcium
CC       channels regulates calcium current density and
CC       activation/inactivation kinetics of the calcium channel. Acts as a
CC       regulatory subunit for P/Q-type calcium channel (CACNA1A), N-type
CC       (CACNA1B), L-type (CACNA1C OR CACNA1D) and possibly T-type
CC       (CACNA1G). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15331424}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer formed of alpha-2-2 and delta-2 chains; disulfide-
CC       linked. Voltage-dependent calcium channels are multisubunit
CC       complexes, consisting of alpha-1 (CACNA1), alpha-2 (CACNA2D), beta
CC       (CACNB) and delta (CACNA2D) subunits in a 1:1:1:1 ratio
CC       (Probable). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11306709}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type I
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=Colocalizes with CACNA1A in
CC       lipid raft fractions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11756448,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16928863}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2a;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-2; Sequence=VSP_028061, VSP_028062;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2c;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-3; Sequence=VSP_028063;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2b;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-4; Sequence=VSP_028061;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-5; Sequence=VSP_028061, VSP_028062, VSP_028063;
CC       Name=6;
CC         IsoId=Q6PHS9-6; Sequence=VSP_028062, VSP_028063;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in brain in a
CC       restricted pattern. Also expressed at lower level in kidney and
CC       testis Not expressed in lung at any moment of development. In
CC       brain, it localizes to sections of P21 brain. Expressed at high
CC       level in the cerebellum, with moderate levels in medulla, pons,
CC       and striatum. Also expressed in cortex, hippocampus, habenula and
CC       nucleus reticularis thalami (nRT). Strongly expressed in
CC       cerebellar Purkinje cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10762351}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The MIDAS-like motif in the VWFA domain binds divalent
CC       metal cations and is required to promote trafficking of the alpha-
CC       1 (CACNA1) subunit to the plasma membrane by an integrin-like
CC       switch.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11306709,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17052222}.
CC   -!- PTM: May be proteolytically processed into subunits alpha-2-2 and
CC       delta-2 that are disulfide-linked. It is however unclear whether
CC       such cleavage really takes place in vivo and has a functional
CC       role. According to PubMed:11306709, it is processed, at least in
CC       vitro, while according to PubMed:17052222, it is only poorly
CC       processed in vivo. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11306709}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Defects in Cacna2d2 are the cause of ducky phenotype
CC       (du). Du mice have spike-wave seizures characteristic of absence
CC       epilepsy and ataxia, with accompanying decreased calcium channel
CC       current in cerebellar Purkinje cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11487633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11756448,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14660671, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17135419}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice exhibit growth retardation, reduced
CC       life span, ataxic gait with apoptosis of cerebellar granule cells
CC       followed by Purkinje cell depletion, enhanced susceptibility to
CC       seizures, and cardiac abnormalities.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15331424}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Binds gabapentin, an antiepileptic drug.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel subunit alpha-2/delta
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAL01651.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=301; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RX   PubMed=21412339; DOI=10.1038/nature09767;

RN   [7]
RP   ENZYME REGULATION.
RX   PubMed=26989199; DOI=10.1126/science.aad6887;
RA   Miller M.R., Mannowetz N., Iavarone A.T., Safavi R., Gracheva E.O.,
RA   Smith J.F., Hill R.Z., Bautista D.M., Kirichok Y., Lishko P.V.;
RT   "Unconventional endocannabinoid signaling governs sperm activation via
RT   sex hormone progesterone.";
RL   Science 352:555-559(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in calcium-dependent physiological responses essential for
CC       successful fertilization, such as sperm hyperactivation, acrosome
CC       reaction and chemotaxis towards the oocyte.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The CatSper calcium channel is indirectly
CC       activated by extracellular progesterone and prostaglandins
CC       following the sequence: progesterone > PGF1-alpha = PGE1 > PGA1 >
CC       PGE2 >> PGD2 (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339, PubMed:26989199).
CC       The CatSper calcium channel is directly inhibited by
CC       endocannabinoid 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2AG) (PubMed:26989199).
CC       Indirect activation by progesterone takes place via the following
CC       mechanism: progesterone binds and activates the acylglycerol
CC       lipase ABHD2, which in turn mediates hydrolysis of 2AG inhibitor,
CC       relieving inhibition of the CatSper channel (PubMed:26989199). The
CC       primary effect of progesterone activation is to shift voltage
CC       dependence towards more physiological, negative membrane
CC       potentials; it is not mediated by metabotropic receptors and
CC       second messengers (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339). Sperm
CC       capacitation enhances the effect of progesterone by providing
CC       additional negative shift. Also activated by the elevation of
CC       intracellular pH (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26989199}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Component of the CatSper
CC       complex. Interacts with CATSPER1 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane;
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein. Note=Specifically located in the
CC       principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q7RTX7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q7RTX7-2; Sequence=VSP_026979, VSP_026980;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12932298,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Wycisk K.A., Zeitz C., Feil S., Wittmer M., Forster U., Neidhardt J.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The alpha-2/delta subunit of voltage-dependent calcium
CC       channels regulates calcium current density and
CC       activation/inactivation kinetics of the calcium channel.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12181424}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer formed of alpha-2-2 and delta-2 chains; disulfide-
CC       linked. Voltage-dependent calcium channels are multisubunit
CC       complexes, consisting of alpha-1 (CACNA1), alpha-2 (CACNA2D), beta
CC       (CACNB) and delta (CACNA2D) subunits in a 1:1:1:1 ratio
CC       (Probable). Interacts with CACNA1C and CACNB3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12181424, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type I
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-4a;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z3S7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z3S7-2; Sequence=VSP_028070;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. May be due to an
CC         intron retention.;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-4b;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z3S7-4; Sequence=VSP_028069;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-4c;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z3S7-5; Sequence=VSP_028071;

CC                                  VSP_044110;
CC         Note=May be produced at very low levels due to a premature stop
CC         codon in the mRNA, leading to nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in certain types of
CC       endocrine cells. Present in the Paneth cells of the small
CC       intestine. Also present in the erythroblasts in the fetal liver,
CC       in the cells of the zona reticularis of the adrenal gland and in
CC       the basophils of the pituitary. Present at low level in some brain
CC       regions such as the cerebellum (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12181424}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The MIDAS-like motif in the VWFA domain binds divalent
CC       metal cations and is required to promote trafficking of the alpha-
CC       1 (CACNA1) subunit to the plasma membrane by an integrin-like
CC       switch. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: May be proteolytically processed into subunits alpha-2-4 and
CC       delta-4 that are disulfide-linked. It is however unclear whether
CC       such cleavage really takes place in vivo and has a functional role
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Retinal cone dystrophy 4 (RCD4) [MIM:610478]:
CC       Characterized by minimal symptoms except for slowly progressive
CC       reduction in visual acuity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17033974}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In contrast to CACNA2D1 and CACNA2D2, it does not
CC       bind gabapentin, an antiepileptic drug.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel subunit alpha-2/delta
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH48288.1; Type=Erroneous translation; Note=Wrong choice of frame.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=23212381; DOI=10.1038/ncomms2257;
RA   Yu Y., Ulbrich M.H., Li M.H., Dobbins S., Zhang W.K., Tong L.,
RA   Isacoff E.Y., Yang J.;
RT   "Molecular mechanism of the assembly of an acid-sensing receptor ion
RT   channel complex.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 3:1252-1252(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of a calcium channel. May act as a sour taste
CC       receptor by forming a calcium channel with PKD1L3 in gustatory
CC       cells; however, its contribution to sour taste perception is
CC       unclear in vivo and may be indirect. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12782129,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19812697, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23212381}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The calcium channel is gated following an off-
CC       response property by acid: gated open after the removal of acid
CC       stimulus, but not during acid application.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18535624, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19464260,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22420714}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Calcium channels are probably composed of 3 subunit of
CC       PKD2L1 and 1 subunit of PKD1L3.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18535624,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20538909, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23212381}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18535624,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20538909, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23212381}.
CC       Note=Interaction with PKD2L1 is required for localization to the
CC       cell membrane.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in placenta, weakly in heart
CC       and lung. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12782129}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: PKD1L3 and PKD2L1 have been defined as sour taste
CC       receptor in gustatory cells based on a number of indirect
CC       evidences in mouse. Some data confirm this hypothesis in human: in
CC       2 patients with sour ageusia that are unresponsive to sour
CC       stimuli, but show normal responses to bitter, sweet, and salty
CC       stimuli, expression of PKD1L3 and PKD2L1 is absent in the anterior
CC       part of the tongue (PubMed:19812697). However, a number of
CC       experiments have recently shown that the sour taste receptor
CC       activity is probably indirect. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19812697}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
