RN   [8]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE CATSPER COMPLEX.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J;
RX   PubMed=21224844; DOI=10.1038/ncomms1153;
RA   Chung J.J., Navarro B., Krapivinsky G., Krapivinsky L., Clapham D.E.;
RT   "A novel gene required for male fertility and functional CATSPER
RT   channel formation in spermatozoa.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 2:153-153(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in sperm cell hyperactivation. Controls calcium entry to mediate
CC       the hyperactivated motility, a step needed for sperm motility
CC       which is essential late in the preparation of sperm for
CC       fertilization. Activated by intracellular alkalinization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17344468}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: In contrast to the human ortholog, not
CC       activated by progesterone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Component of the CatSper
CC       complex. Interacts with CATSPER1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224844, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q91ZR5:Catsper1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15619135, EBI-15619083;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}. Note=Specifically located in the
CC       principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q80W99-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q80W99-2; Sequence=VSP_026978;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected in hte testis during postnatal
CC       development at day 15. Restricted to the late-stage germline cells
CC       that line the seminiferous tubules. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice are normal but males are sterile. Male
CC       sterility is due to defects in sperm motility unability to
CC       fertilize intact eggs. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17344468}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH89518.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Contaminating sequence.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, INTERACTION WITH
RP   CATSPER1, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=17227845; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0610286104;

RP   LACK OF ACTIVATION BY PROGESTERONE AND PGE1.
RX   PubMed=21412339; DOI=10.1038/nature09767;

RL   Nature 471:387-391(2011).
RN   [9]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE CATSPER COMPLEX.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J;
RX   PubMed=21224844; DOI=10.1038/ncomms1153;
RA   Chung J.J., Navarro B., Krapivinsky G., Krapivinsky L., Clapham D.E.;
RT   "A novel gene required for male fertility and functional CATSPER
RT   channel formation in spermatozoa.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 2:153-153(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in sperm cell hyperactivation. Controls calcium entry to mediate
CC       the hyperactivated motility, a step needed for sperm motility
CC       which is essential late in the preparation of sperm for
CC       fertilization. Activated by intracellular alkalinization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17344468}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: In contrast to the human ortholog, not
CC       activated by progesterone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Component of the CatSper
CC       complex. Interacts with CATSPER1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224844, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q91ZR5:Catsper1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15619199, EBI-15619083;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}. Note=Specifically located in the
CC       principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107607,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected in hte testis during postnatal
CC       development at day 15. Restricted to the late-stage germline cells
CC       that line the seminiferous tubules. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice are normal but males are sterile. Male
CC       sterility is due to defects in sperm motility unability to
CC       fertilize intact eggs. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17344468}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAM21941.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=20547763; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M110.129833;
RA   Tugba Durlu-Kandilci N., Ruas M., Chuang K.T., Brading A.,
RA   Parrington J., Galione A.;
RT   "TPC2 proteins mediate nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate
RT   (NAADP)- and agonist-evoked contractions of smooth muscle.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 285:24925-24932(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAADP)
CC       receptor that may function as one of the major voltage-gated
CC       Ca(2+) channels (VDCC) across the lysosomal membrane. Involved in
CC       smooth muscle contraction. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19387438,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20495006, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20547763}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (PubMed:19557428). Interacts with LRRK2.
CC       Interacts with HAX1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NHX9, ECO:0000305|PubMed:19557428}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Lysosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19557428, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20495006}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19557428,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20495006}. Note=Only the acidic lysosomal
CC       fraction is sensitive to NAADP.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8BWC0-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8BWC0-2; Sequence=VSP_023009, VSP_023010;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8BWC0-3; Sequence=VSP_023008;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19557428}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two internal repeats contains five hydrophobic
CC       transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one positively
CC       charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments probably represent
CC       the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a series of positively
CC       charged amino acids at every third position (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORMS 1 AND 2).
RC   STRAIN=Berkeley; TISSUE=Embryo, and Head;
RA   Celniker S., Carlson J., Wan K., Pfeiffer B., Frise E., George R.,
RA   Hoskins R., Stapleton M., Pacleb J., Park S., Svirskas R., Smith E.,
RA   Yu C., Rubin G.;
RL   Submitted (SEP-2006) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria. Constitutes a pore-
CC       forming and calcium-conducting subunit. Mitochondrial calcium
CC       homeostasis plays key roles in cellular physiology and regulates
CC       cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium signals and activation of
CC       cell death pathways. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by ruthenium red or its derivative
CC       Ru360. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=A {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185}, B
CC       {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185}, C
CC       {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185}, D
CC       {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185};
CC         IsoId=Q8IQ70-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=G {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185};
CC         IsoId=Q8IQ70-2; Sequence=VSP_058493;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=E {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185};
CC         IsoId=Q8IQ70-3; Sequence=VSP_058492;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=H {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185};
CC         IsoId=Q8IQ70-4; Sequence=VSP_058494;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=I {ECO:0000312|FlyBase:FBgn0042185};
CC         IsoId=Q8IQ70-5; Sequence=VSP_058495;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Forms a well-packed pentamer with an overall cylindrical
CC       shape. The inner core of the pentamer is formed with the second
CC       transmembrane region and the second coiled-coil region: while the
CC       transmembrane regions pack into a five-helix bundle having a
CC       largely polar pore across the membrane, the coiled-coil outside
CC       the membrane forms a pentamer with a hydrophobic core. The inner
CC       core is wrapped by the first transmembrane region through contacts
CC       between the first and the second transmembrane regions. The second
CC       transmembrane is followed by the inner juxtamembrane region (IJMH)
CC       that orients at a wide angle relative to the second transmembrane.
CC       The two core domains are held together on the periphery by the
CC       outer juxtamembrane helix (OJMH). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The critical DXXE motif connecting the transmembrane
CC       regions forms a pentameric barrel that constitutes the mouth of
CC       the pore. Inside the barrel, two acidic residues are in position
CC       to form two carboxylate rings. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MCU (TC 1.A.77) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [18]
RP   VARIANT PRO-86.
RX   PubMed=21378601; DOI=10.1097/YPG.0b013e3283457bcc;
RA   Feher A., Juhasz A., Rimanoczy A., Pakaski M., Kalman J., Janka Z.;
RT   "No association between CALHM1 polymorphism and Alzheimer's disease
RT   risk in a Hungarian population.";
RL   Psychiatr. Genet. 21:249-252(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming subunit of a voltage-gated ion channel
CC       required for sensory perception of sweet, bitter and umami tastes.
CC       Specifically present in type II taste bud cells, where it plays a
CC       central role in sweet, bitter and umami taste perception by
CC       inducing ATP release from the cell, ATP acting as a
CC       neurotransmitter to activate afferent neural gustatory pathways.
CC       Acts both as a voltage-gated and calcium-activated ion channel:
CC       mediates neuronal excitability in response to changes in
CC       extracellular Ca(2+) concentration. Has poor ion selectivity and
CC       forms a wide pore (around 14 Angstroms) that mediates permeation
CC       of Ca(2+), Na(+) and K(+), as well as permeation of monovalent
CC       anions. Acts as an activator of the ERK1 and ERK2 cascade.
CC       Triggers endoplasmic reticulum stress by reducing the calcium
CC       content of the endoplasmic reticulum. May indirectly control
CC       amyloid precursor protein (APP) proteolysis and aggregated
CC       amyloid-beta (Abeta) peptides levels in a Ca(2+) dependent manner.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21574960,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22711817, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23300080,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23345406}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Gd(3+), Ruthenium Red, and Zn(2+)
CC       and partially inhibited by 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22711817}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23300080}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1790341, EBI-1790341;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22711817,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23300080}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350}; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Note=Colocalizes with HSPA5 at the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in adult brain.
CC       Detected also in retinoic acid-differentiated SH-SY5Y cells.
CC       Specifically expressed in circumvallate taste bud cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19997627}.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Leu-86 causes a dysregulation of Ca(2+) homeostasis
CC       and amyloid precursor protein (APP) metabolism and has been
CC       suggested to be a risk factor for the development of Alzheimer
CC       disease (PubMed:18585350, PubMed:20061624, PubMed:20164592).
CC       However, this association with Alzheimer disease could not be
CC       confirmed in a number of studies performed in different
CC       populations (PubMed:19472444, PubMed:19070563, PubMed:19191331,
CC       PubMed:19191332, PubMed:19545933, PubMed:19655363,
CC       PubMed:21378601). According to a meta-analysis study, Leu-86 is
CC       likely not a genetic determinant of Alzheimer disease but may
CC       modulate age of onset by interacting with the effect of the APOE*4
CC       allele of the APOE gene (PubMed:20847397).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585350, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19070563,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19191331, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19191332,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19472444, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19545933,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19655363, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20061624,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20164592, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20847397,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21378601}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CALHM family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [4]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=11687876; DOI=10.1007/s00232-001-0072-7;
RA   Gong H.C., Hang J., Kohler W., Li L., Su T.-Z.;
RT   "Tissue-specific expression and gabapentin-binding properties of
RT   calcium channel alpha2delta subunit subtypes.";
RL   J. Membr. Biol. 184:35-43(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The alpha-2/delta subunit of voltage-dependent calcium
CC       channels regulates calcium current density and
CC       activation/inactivation kinetics of the calcium channel. Acts as a
CC       regulatory subunit for P/Q-type calcium channel (CACNA1A), N-type
CC       (CACNA1B), L-type (CACNA1C OR CACNA1D) but not T-type (CACNA1G)
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer formed of alpha-2-2 and delta-2 chains; disulfide-
CC       linked. Voltage-dependent calcium channels are multisubunit
CC       complexes, consisting of alpha-1 (CACNA1), alpha-2 (CACNA2D), beta
CC       (CACNB) and delta (CACNA2D) subunits in a 1:1:1:1 ratio (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type I
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8IZS8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8IZS8-2; Sequence=VSP_028064;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8IZS8-3; Sequence=VSP_028064, VSP_028065, VSP_028066,
CC                                  VSP_028067;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Only detected in brain. Not present in lung,
CC       testis, aorta, spleen, jejunum, ventricular muscle and kidney (at
CC       protein level). According to PubMed:11687876, it is brain-
CC       specific, while according to PubMed:11245980, it is widely
CC       expressed. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11687876}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The MIDAS-like motif in the VWFA domain binds divalent
CC       metal cations and is required to promote trafficking of the alpha-
CC       1 (CACNA1) subunit to the plasma membrane by an integrin-like
CC       switch. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: May be proteolytically processed into subunits alpha-2-3 and
CC       delta-3 that are disulfide-linked. It is however unclear whether
CC       such cleavage really takes place in vivo and has a functional role
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In contrast to CACNA2D1 and CACNA2D2, it does not
CC       bind gabapentin, an antiepileptic drug.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel subunit alpha-2/delta
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [31]
RP   INTERACTION WITH MCUR1.
RX   PubMed=26976564; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1602264113;
RA   Chaudhuri D., Artiga D.J., Abiria S.A., Clapham D.E.;

RN   [32]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.50 ANGSTROMS) OF 75-185, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT,
RP   INTERACTION WITH MCUR1; MICU1 AND MICU2, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION,
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF SER-92 AND LYS-180, AND DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=26341627; DOI=10.15252/embr.201540436;
RA   Lee Y., Min C.K., Kim T.G., Song H.K., Lim Y., Kim D., Shin K.,
RA   Kang M., Kang J.Y., Youn H.S., Lee J.G., An J.Y., Park K.R., Lim J.J.,
RA   Kim J.H., Kim J.H., Park Z.Y., Kim Y.S., Wang J., Kim D.H., Eom S.H.;
RT   "Structure and function of the N-terminal domain of the human
RT   mitochondrial calcium uniporter.";
RL   EMBO Rep. 16:1318-1333(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria (PubMed:21685888,
CC       PubMed:21685886, PubMed:23101630, PubMed:22904319,
CC       PubMed:23178883, PubMed:22829870, PubMed:22822213,
CC       PubMed:24332854, PubMed:23755363, PubMed:26341627). Constitutes
CC       the pore-forming and calcium-conducting subunit of the uniporter
CC       complex (uniplex) (PubMed:23755363). Activity is regulated by
CC       MICU1 and MICU2. At low Ca(2+) levels MCU activity is down-
CC       regulated by MICU1 and MICU2; at higher Ca(2+) levels MICU1
CC       increases MCU activity (PubMed:24560927, PubMed:26903221).
CC       Mitochondrial calcium homeostasis plays key roles in cellular
CC       physiology and regulates cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium
CC       signals and activation of cell death pathways. Involved in
CC       buffering the amplitude of systolic calcium rises in
CC       cardiomyocytes (PubMed:22822213). While dispensable for baseline
CC       homeostatic cardiac function, acts as a key regulator of short-
CC       term mitochondrial calcium loading underlying a 'fight-or-flight'
CC       response during acute stress: acts by mediating a rapid increase
CC       of mitochondrial calcium in pacemaker cells (PubMed:25603276).
CC       participates in mitochondrial permeability transition during
CC       ischemia-reperfusion injury (By similarity). Regulates glucose-
CC       dependent insulin secretion in pancreatic beta-cells by regulating
CC       mitochondrial calcium uptake (PubMed:22904319, PubMed:22829870).
CC       Mitochondrial calcium uptake in skeletal muscle cells is involved
CC       in muscle size in adults (By similarity). Regulates synaptic
CC       vesicle endocytosis kinetics in central nerve terminal (By
CC       similarity). Involved in antigen processing and presentation (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q3UMR5,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685886, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685888,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22822213, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22829870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904319, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23101630,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23178883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23755363,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24332854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24560927,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25603276, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26341627,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26903221}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by ruthenium red or its derivative
CC       Ru360. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23755363}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the uniplex complex, composed of MCU, MCUB,
CC       MICU1, MICU2 and EMRE/SMDT1 (PubMed:24231807). Homooligomer
CC       (PubMed:21685886, PubMed:26341627). Forms a pentamer (By
CC       similarity). Heterooligomer with CCDC109B/MCUB; this inhibits
CC       channel activity (By similarity). Interacts with MICU1; MICU1 acts
CC       as an essential regulator for MCU (PubMed:21685886,
CC       PubMed:23101630, PubMed:23178883, PubMed:24332854,
CC       PubMed:26341627). Interacts with MCUR1 (PubMed:23178883,
CC       PubMed:26341627, PubMed:27184846, PubMed:26976564). Interacts with
CC       CCDC90B (PubMed:27184846). Interactions with MICU1 and MCUR1 are
CC       mutually exclusive (PubMed:23178883). Interacts with MICU2
CC       (PubMed:26341627). Interacts with SLC25A23 (PubMed:24430870).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q3UMR5,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685886, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23101630,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23178883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24231807,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24332854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24430870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26341627, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26976564,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27184846}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q96AQ8:MCUR1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-15932889, EBI-14404755;
CC       Q9BPX6:MICU1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15932889, EBI-2371996;
CC       Q9BPX6-1:MICU1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15932889, EBI-5456336;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685886, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685888,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23755363, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24231807,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27099988, ECO:0000305|PubMed:26341627}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685886,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685888, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24231807}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8NE86-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8NE86-2; Sequence=VSP_024263;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8NE86-3; Sequence=VSP_041687;
CC   -!- INDUCTION: MCU transcripts are down-regulated by microRNA miR-25
CC       (PubMed:23246404). Down-regulation by miR-25 may protect
CC       cardiomyocytes against oxidative damage in cardiomyocytes
CC       (PubMed:25764156). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23246404,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25764156}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal MCU domain is required for efficient Ca(2+)
CC       uptake and for interaction with MCUR1. It is not required for
CC       targeting to the mitochondria, oligomerization, interaction with
CC       MICU1 and MICU2, or assembly of the uniplex complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26341627}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Forms a well-packed pentamer with an overall cylindrical
CC       shape. The inner core of the pentamer is formed with the second
CC       transmembrane region and the second coiled-coil region: while the
CC       transmembrane regions pack into a five-helix bundle having a
CC       largely polar pore across the membrane, the coiled-coil outside
CC       the membrane forms a pentamer with a hydrophobic core. The inner
CC       core is wrapped by the first transmembrane region through contacts
CC       between the first and the second transmembrane regions. The second
CC       transmembrane is followed by the inner juxtamembrane region (IJMH)
CC       that orients at a wide angle relative to the second transmembrane.
CC       The two core domains are held together on the periphery by the
CC       outer juxtamembrane helix (OJMH). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The critical DXXE motif connecting the transmembrane
CC       regions forms a pentameric barrel that constitutes the mouth of
CC       the pore. Inside the barrel, two acidic residues are in position
CC       to form two carboxylate rings. In absence of SMDT1/EMRE regulator,
CC       the calcium ions cannot exit the channel, suggesting that
CC       SMDT1/EMRE-binding induces conformational rearrangements to allow
CC       calcium to exit. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q21121}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation by CaMK2 in heart leads to increased MCU
CC       current (PubMed:23051746, PubMed:25254481). The regulation of MCU
CC       by CaMK2 is however subject to discussion: another group was
CC       unable to reproduce these results (PubMed:25254480).
CC       Phosphorylated on tyrosines by PTK2B/PYK2, promoting
CC       oligomerization (PubMed:24800979). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24800979,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:23051746, ECO:0000305|PubMed:25254480,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:25254481}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MCU (TC 1.A.77) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   ENZYME REGULATION.
RX   PubMed=26989199; DOI=10.1126/science.aad6887;
RA   Miller M.R., Mannowetz N., Iavarone A.T., Safavi R., Gracheva E.O.,
RA   Smith J.F., Hill R.Z., Bautista D.M., Kirichok Y., Lishko P.V.;
RT   "Unconventional endocannabinoid signaling governs sperm activation via
RT   sex hormone progesterone.";
RL   Science 352:555-559(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in calcium-dependent physiological responses essential for
CC       successful fertilization, such as sperm hyperactivation, acrosome
CC       reaction and chemotaxis towards the oocyte.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The CatSper calcium channel is indirectly
CC       activated by extracellular progesterone and prostaglandins
CC       following the sequence: progesterone > PGF1-alpha = PGE1 > PGA1 >
CC       PGE2 >> PGD2 (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339, PubMed:26989199).
CC       The CatSper calcium channel is directly inhibited by
CC       endocannabinoid 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2AG) (PubMed:26989199).
CC       Indirect activation by progesterone takes place via the following
CC       mechanism: progesterone binds and activates the acylglycerol
CC       lipase ABHD2, which in turn mediates hydrolysis of 2AG inhibitor,
CC       relieving inhibition of the CatSper channel (PubMed:26989199). The
CC       primary effect of progesterone activation is to shift voltage
CC       dependence towards more physiological, negative membrane
CC       potentials; it is not mediated by metabotropic receptors and
CC       second messengers (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339). Sperm
CC       capacitation enhances the effect of progesterone by providing
CC       additional negative shift. Also activated by the elevation of
CC       intracellular pH (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26989199}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Component of the CatSper
CC       complex. Interacts with CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with Ca(v)3.3/CACNA1I, leading to suppress T-type
CC       calcium channel activity. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16740636, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       O95994:AGR2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-712648;
CC       P02652:APOA2; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-1171525;
CC       Q9P0X4:CACNA1I; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-1220829;
CC       Q9UKJ5:CHIC2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-741528;
CC       Q9H2X0:CHRD; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-947551;
CC       P50402:EMD; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-489887;
CC       P08151:GLI1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-308084;

CC       Q9UFD9:RIMBP3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-744545, EBI-10182375;

CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16625279}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16625279}. Note=Specifically located in the
CC       principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16625279, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed meiotically and post-meiotically.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16625279}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Down-regulated in patients lacking sperm motility.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14688170}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spermatogenic failure 7 (SPGF7) [MIM:612997]: An
CC       infertility disorder characterized by non-motile sperm or sperm
CC       motility below the normal threshold, low sperm count, increased
CC       abnormally structured spermatozoa, and reduced semen volume.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19344877}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Putative receptor-activated non-selective calcium
CC       permeant cation channel. It is activated by innocuous (warm)
CC       temperatures and shows an increased response at noxious
CC       temperatures greater than 39 degrees Celsius. Activation exhibits
CC       an outward rectification. May associate with TRPV1 and may
CC       modulate its activity. Is a negative regulator of hair growth and
CC       cycling: TRPV3-coupled signaling suppresses keratinocyte
CC       proliferation in hair follicles and induces apoptosis and
CC       premature hair follicle regression (catagen).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12077604, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12077606,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21593771}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form a heteromeric channel with TRPV1. Interacts with
CC       TRPV1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12077606}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8NET8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q8NET8-2; Sequence=VSP_013433;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=B;
CC         IsoId=Q8NET8-3; Sequence=VSP_013434, VSP_013435;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Abundantly expressed in CNS. Widely expressed
CC       at low levels. Detected in dorsal root ganglion (at protein
CC       level). Expressed in the keratinocyte layers of the outer root
CC       sheath and, to lesser extent, to the matrix of the hair follicles
CC       (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12077604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12077606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21593771}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Olmsted syndrome (OLMS) [MIM:614594]: A rare congenital
CC       disorder characterized by bilateral mutilating palmoplantar
CC       keratoderma and periorificial keratotic plaques with severe
CC       itching at all lesions. Diffuse alopecia, constriction of digits,
CC       and onychodystrophy have also been reported. Infections and
CC       squamous cell carcinomas can arise on the keratotic areas. The
CC       digital constriction may progress to autoamputation of fingers and
CC       toes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22405088, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22835024}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Palmoplantar keratoderma, non-epidermolytic, focal 2
CC       (FNEPPK2) [MIM:616400]: A dermatological disorder characterized by
CC       non-epidermolytic, abnormal thickening of the skin on the palms
CC       and soles. Focal palmoplantar keratoderma consists of localized
CC       areas of hyperkeratosis located mainly on pressure points and
CC       sites of recurrent friction. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25285920}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       TrpV subfamily. TRPV3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Transient receptor potential cation channel,
CC       subfamily V, member 3 (TRPV3); Note=Leiden Open Variation Database
CC       (LOVD);
CC       URL="https://databases.lovd.nl/shared/genes/TRPV3";

RL   Nat. Genet. 40:835-837(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAADP)
CC       receptor that may function as one of the major voltage-gated
CC       Ca(2+) channels (VDCC) across the lysosomal membrane. May be
CC       involved in smooth muscle contraction.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19387438, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (By similarity). Interacts with LRRK2
CC       (PubMed:22012985). Interacts with HAX1 (PubMed:24188827).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8BWC0, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22012985,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24188827}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-5239949, EBI-5239949;
CC       O00165:HAX1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-5239949, EBI-357001;
CC       P42345:MTOR; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-5239949, EBI-359260;
CC       Q9ULQ1:TPCN1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-5239949, EBI-5239895;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Lysosome membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Note=Only the acidic lysosomal
CC       fraction is sensitive to NAADP. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed. Expressed at high level in
CC       liver and kidney. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19387438}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two internal repeats contains five hydrophobic
CC       transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one positively
CC       charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments probably represent
CC       the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a series of positively
CC       charged amino acids at every third position (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Genetic variants in TPCN2 define the skin/hair/eye
CC       pigmentation variation locus 10 (SHEP10) [MIM:612267]. Hair, eye
CC       and skin pigmentation are among the most visible examples of human
CC       phenotypic variation, with a broad normal range that is subject to
CC       substantial geographic stratification. In the case of skin,
CC       individuals tend to have lighter pigmentation with increasing
CC       distance from the equator. By contrast, the majority of variation
CC       in human eye and hair color is found among individuals of European
CC       ancestry, with most other human populations fixed for brown eyes
CC       and black hair. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18488028}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. Two pore calcium channel subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=24336289; DOI=10.1038/nature12832;
RA   DeCaen P.G., Delling M., Vien T.N., Clapham D.E.;
RT   "Direct recording and molecular identification of the calcium channel
RT   of primary cilia.";
RL   Nature 504:315-318(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of a ciliary calcium channel that controls
CC       calcium concentration within primary cilia without affecting
CC       cytoplasmic calcium concentration. Forms a heterodimer with PKD2L1
CC       in primary cilia and forms a calcium-permeant ciliary channel that
CC       regulates sonic hedgehog/SHH signaling and GLI2 transcription.
CC       Does not constitute the pore-forming subunit. Also involved in
CC       left/right axis specification downstream of nodal flow: forms a
CC       complex with PKD2 in cilia to facilitate flow detection in
CC       left/right patterning. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer; heterodimerizes with PKD2 proteins to form a
CC       calcium channel. Interacts with PKD2L1; to form ciliary calcium
CC       channel. Interacts with PKD2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In testis, strong expression in Leydig cells,
CC       low level in seminal ducts, myoid cells and tunica vaginalis.
CC       Other tissues, including adrenal gland and heart myocardium, also
CC       show low expression. In embryo, highly expressed in the node.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Situs inversus in approximately one third of
CC       the homozygous mutant mice. No other notable phenotype (such as
CC       espiratory tract lesions, hydrocephalus, and male infertility) is
CC       observed. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20080492}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nonselective ligand-gated cation channel probably
CC       playing a role in the regulation of membrane trafficking events.
CC       Acts as Ca(2+)-permeable cation channel with inwardly rectifying
CC       activity (PubMed:18369318, PubMed:19497048, PubMed:19522758,
CC       PubMed:19885840, PubMed:29106414). Mediates release of Ca(2+) from
CC       endosomes to the cytoplasm, contributes to endosomal acidification
CC       and is involved in the regulation of membrane trafficking and
CC       fusion in the endosomal pathway (PubMed:21245134). Does not seem
CC       to act as mechanosensory transduction channel in inner ear sensory
CC       hair cells. Proposed to play a critical role at the cochlear
CC       stereocilia ankle-link region during hair-bundle growth (By
CC       similarity). Involved in the regulation of autophagy
CC       (PubMed:19522758). Through association with GABARAPL2 may be
CC       involved in autophagosome formation possibly providing Ca(2+) for
CC       the fusion process (By similarity). Through a possible and
CC       probably tissue-specific heteromerization with MCOLN1 may be at
CC       least in part involved in many lysosome-dependent cellular events
CC       (PubMed:19885840). Possible heteromeric ion channel assemblies
CC       with TRPV5 show pharmacological similarity with TRPML3
CC       (PubMed:23469151). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8R4F0,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18369318, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19497048,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19885840,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20378547, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21245134,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23469151, ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by lumenal H(+) and Na(+)
CC       (PubMed:18369318, PubMed:29106414). The channel pore shows dynamic
CC       behavior and undergoes spontaneous, Ca(2+)-dependent modulation
CC       when conducting Ca(2+) (PubMed:20378547).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18369318, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20378547,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:29106414). Can heterooligomerize
CC       with MCOLN1; heteromeric assemblies have different channel
CC       properties as compared to the respective homooligomers and may be
CC       tissue-specific (PubMed:19885840). May heterooligomerize with
CC       TRPV5 to form a functional distinct ion channel (PubMed:23469151).
CC       Interacts with GABARAPL2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8R4F0, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19885840,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414, ECO:0000305|PubMed:23469151}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}. Early endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19497048, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}. Late endosome
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19497048,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}. Lysosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:29106414}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, autophagosome
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758}. Note=Recycles between the
CC       plasma membrane and intracellular compartments by a dynamin-
CC       dependent endocytic pathway (PubMed:19522758). Under normal
CC       conditions, only a very minor proportion is present at the cell
CC       membrane (PubMed:19522758). In the cochlea located at the base of
CC       stereocilia near the position of the ankle links (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8R4F0, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19522758}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDD5-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDD5-2; Sequence=VSP_010823;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The most N-terminal extracellular/lumenal domain (referred
CC       to as I-II linker or polycystin-mucolipin domain) contributes to a
CC       structure with a four-fold rotational symmetry in a tetrameric
CC       assembly; the structure contains a central highly electronegative
CC       pore with a 14 A diameter. The pore is critical for Ca(2+) and pH
CC       regulation. The protruding structure formed by the I-II linkers
CC       may contain all the interaction sites with lipids and proteins in
CC       the endolysosomal lumen. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9GZU1}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19885840}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       Polycystin subfamily. MCOLN3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of a ciliary calcium channel that controls
CC       calcium concentration within primary cilia without affecting
CC       cytoplasmic calcium concentration. Forms a heterodimer with PKD2L1
CC       in primary cilia and forms a calcium-permeant ciliary channel that
CC       regulates sonic hedgehog/SHH signaling and GLI2 transcription.
CC       Does not constitute the pore-forming subunit. Also involved in
CC       left/right axis specification downstream of nodal flow: forms a
CC       complex with PKD2 in cilia to facilitate flow detection in
CC       left/right patterning. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer; heterodimerizes with PKD2 proteins to form a
CC       calcium channel. Interacts with PKD2L1; to form ciliary calcium
CC       channel. Interacts with PKD2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDX9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDX9-2; Sequence=VSP_013215, VSP_013216;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in testis and in fetal and adult
CC       heart.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Heterotaxy, visceral, 8, autosomal (HTX8) [MIM:617205]: A
CC       form of visceral heterotaxy, a complex disorder due to disruption
CC       of the normal left-right asymmetry of the thoracoabdominal organs.
CC       Visceral heterotaxy or situs ambiguus results in randomization of
CC       the placement of visceral organs, including the heart, lungs,
CC       liver, spleen, and stomach. The organs are oriented randomly with
CC       respect to the left-right axis and with respect to one another. It
CC       can been associated with a variety of congenital defects including
CC       cardiac malformations. HTX8 inheritance is autosomal recessive.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27616478}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAQ89117.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   SUBUNIT, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RX   PubMed=19265014; DOI=10.1126/science.1167852;
RA   Schwenk J., Harmel N., Zolles G., Bildl W., Kulik A., Heimrich B.,
RA   Chisaka O., Jonas P., Schulte U., Fakler B., Kloecker N.;
RT   "Functional proteomics identify cornichon proteins as auxiliary
RT   subunits of AMPA receptors.";
RL   Science 323:1313-1319(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulates the gating properties of AMPA-selective
CC       glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Modulates their gating properties by
CC       accelerating their rates of activation, deactivation and
CC       desensitization. Displays subunit-specific AMPA receptor
CC       regulation. Shows specificity for GRIA1, GRIA4 and the long
CC       isoform of GRIA2. According to PubMed:18817736, shows only
CC       specificity for GRIA2 and specifically to the form of GRIA2 for
CC       which a single amino acid in the pore region has been edited from
CC       a glutamine to an arginine residue. Thought to stabilize the
CC       calcium channel in an inactivated (closed) state.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18817736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19234459}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The L-type calcium channel is composed of five subunits:
CC       alpha-1, alpha-2/delta, beta and gamma. Acts as an auxiliary
CC       subunit for AMPA-selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Found in
CC       a complex with GRIA1, GRIA2, GRIA3, GRIA4, CNIH2, CNIH3, CACNG2,
CC       CACNG3, CACNG4, CACNG7 and CACNG8. Interacts with GRIA1, GRIA2,
CC       GRIA3 and GRIA4. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18817736,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19234459, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19265014}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane, postsynaptic density {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18817736}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PMP-22/EMP/MP20 family. CACNG
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21172611; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2010.11.026;
RA   Kato A.S., Gill M.B., Ho M.T., Yu H., Tu Y., Siuda E.R., Wang H.,

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=20805473; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1011706107;
RA   Shi Y., Suh Y.H., Milstein A.D., Isozaki K., Schmid S.M., Roche K.W.,
RA   Nicoll R.A.;
RT   "Functional comparison of the effects of TARPs and cornichons on AMPA
RT   receptor trafficking and gating.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:16315-16319(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulates the trafficking and gating properties of AMPA-
CC       selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Promotes their targeting
CC       to the cell membrane and synapses and modulates their gating
CC       properties by slowing their rates of activation, deactivation and
CC       desensitization and by mediating their resensitization. Does not
CC       show subunit-specific AMPA receptor regulation and regulates all
CC       AMPAR subunits. Thought to stabilize the calcium channel in an
CC       inactivated (closed) state. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20805473,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21172611}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The L-type calcium channel is composed of five subunits:
CC       alpha-1, alpha-2/delta, beta and gamma. Acts as an auxiliary
CC       subunit for AMPA-selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Found in
CC       a complex with GRIA1, GRIA2, GRIA3, GRIA4, CNIH2, CNIH3, CACNG2,
CC       CACNG3, CACNG4, CACNG5 and CACNG7. Interacts with CNIH2 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane, postsynaptic density {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PMP-22/EMP/MP20 family. CACNG
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAK15019.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Contaminating sequence. Sequence of unknown origin in the N-terminal part.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN A COMPLEX WITH CATSPERB; CATSPERG2 AND HSPA1B.
RX   PubMed=19516020; DOI=10.1095/biolreprod.109.077107;
RA   Wang H., Liu J., Cho K.-H., Ren D.;
RT   "A novel, single, transmembrane protein CATSPERG is associated with
RT   CATSPER1 channel protein.";
RL   Biol. Reprod. 81:539-544(2009).
RN   [12]
RP   LACK OF ACTIVATION BY PROGESTERONE AND PGE1.
RX   PubMed=21412339; DOI=10.1038/nature09767;
RA   Lishko P.V., Botchkina I.L., Kirichok Y.;
RT   "Progesterone activates the principal Ca2+ channel of human sperm.";
RL   Nature 471:387-391(2011).
RN   [13]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE CATSPER COMPLEX.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J;
RX   PubMed=21224844; DOI=10.1038/ncomms1153;
RA   Chung J.J., Navarro B., Krapivinsky G., Krapivinsky L., Clapham D.E.;
RT   "A novel gene required for male fertility and functional CATSPER
RT   channel formation in spermatozoa.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 2:153-153(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in sperm cell hyperactivation. Controls calcium entry to mediate
CC       the hyperactivated motility, a step needed for sperm motility
CC       which is essential late in the preparation of sperm for
CC       fertilization. Activated by intracellular alkalinization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14657352,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16036917, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16467839,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17174296}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: In contrast to the human ortholog, not
CC       activated by progesterone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Interacts with
CC       Ca(v)3.3/CACNA1I, leading to suppress T-type calcium channel
CC       activity (By similarity). Component of the CatSper complex.
CC       Interacts with CATSPER3 and CATSPER4. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227845, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17478420,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19516020, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224844,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q80W99:Catsper3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15619083, EBI-15619135;
CC       Q8BVN3:Catsper4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15619083, EBI-15619199;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941}. Note=Specifically located in the
CC       principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected only after round spermatids are
CC       produced approximately at day 18. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14688170,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice are normal but males are sterile. Male
CC       sterility is due to defects in sperm motility unability to
CC       fertilize intact eggs. In mice lacking Catsper1, sperm lacks
CC       CatSper2 protein, while in mice lacking CatSper1, sperm lacks
CC       CatSper1 protein, suggesting that stable expression of CatSper1
CC       protein requires CatSper2 and vice versa.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11595941}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [10]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.8 ANGSTROMS) OF 1551-1828, COFACTOR, AND
RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=11389851; DOI=10.1016/S1097-2765(01)00256-8;
RA   Yamaguchi H., Matsushita M., Nairn A.C., Kuriyan J.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the atypical protein kinase domain of a TRP
RT   channel with phosphotransferase activity.";
RL   Mol. Cell 7:1047-1057(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential ion channel and serine/threonine-protein
CC       kinase. Divalent cation channel permeable to calcium and
CC       magnesium. Has a central role in magnesium ion homeostasis and in
CC       the regulation of anoxic neuronal cell death. Involved in TNF-
CC       induced necroptosis downstream of MLKL by mediating calcium
CC       influx. The kinase activity is essential for the channel function.
CC       May be involved in a fundamental process that adjusts plasma
CC       membrane divalent cation fluxes according to the metabolic state
CC       of the cell. Phosphorylates annexin A1 (ANXA1).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11385574}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11389851};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11389851};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heterodimers with TRPM6. Interacts with PLCB1 (By
CC       similarity). Homodimer. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11389851}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P60710:Actb; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8010314, EBI-353957;
CC       Q3U1J4:Ddb1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8010314, EBI-2552275;
CC       O00571:DDX3X (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8010314, EBI-353779;
CC       Q8VDD5:Myh9; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-8010314, EBI-400906;
CC       Q8N488:RYBP (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8010314, EBI-752324;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Found to be expressed in brain and skeletal
CC       muscle, with stronger signals in kidney, heart, liver and spleen.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11161216}.
CC   -!- PTM: Autophosphorylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11161216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22222377}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the protein
CC       kinase superfamily. Alpha-type protein kinase family. ALPK
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the transient
CC       receptor (TC 1.A.4) family. LTrpC subfamily. TRPM7 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS CVPT1 SER-3946; THR-4124; PRO-4158 AND
RP   PRO-4159, MUTAGENESIS OF GLY-3946; MET-3978 AND HIS-4108, AND
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27733687; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M116.756528;
RA   Xiao Z., Guo W., Sun B., Hunt D.J., Wei J., Liu Y., Wang Y., Wang R.,
RA   Jones P.P., Back T.G., Chen S.R.;
RT   "Enhanced cytosolic Ca2+ activation underlies a common defect of
RT   central domain cardiac ryanodine receptor mutations linked to
RT   arrhythmias.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 291:24528-24537(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel that mediates the release of Ca(2+) from
CC       the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm and thereby plays a
CC       key role in triggering cardiac muscle contraction. Aberrant
CC       channel activation can lead to cardiac arrhythmia. In cardiac
CC       myocytes, calcium release is triggered by increased Ca(2+) levels
CC       due to activation of the L-type calcium channel CACNA1C. The
CC       calcium channel activity is modulated by formation of
CC       heterotetramers with RYR3. Required for cellular calcium ion
CC       homeostasis. Required for embryonic heart development.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056922,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27733687}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open Ca-release channel with high
CC       affinity. At low concentrations, ryanodine maintains the channel
CC       in an open conformation. High ryanodine concentrations inhibit
CC       channel activity. Channel activity is regulated by calmodulin
CC       (CALM). The calcium release is activated by increased cytoplasmic
CC       calcium levels, by nitric oxyde (NO), caffeine and ATP. Channel
CC       activity is inhibited by magnesium ions, possibly by competition
CC       for calcium binding sites. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11716}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Can also form heterotetramers with RYR1 and
CC       RYR3 (By similarity). Interacts with FKBP1A and FKBP1B; these
CC       interactions may stabilize the channel in its closed state and
CC       prevent Ca(2+) leaks. Interacts with CALM and S100A1; these
CC       interactions regulate channel activity. Identified in a complex
CC       composed of RYR2, FKBP1B, PKA catalytic subunit, PRKAR2A, AKAP6,
CC       and the protein phosphatases PP2A and PP1. Interacts directly with
CC       FKBP1B, PKA, PP1 and PP2A. Interacts with SELENON (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P30957, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18650434}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P62942:FKBP1A; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-1027571;
CC       P68106:FKBP1B; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-6693977;
CC       Q00987:MDM2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-389668;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10830164}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10830164}. Sarcoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P30957}. Note=The number of predicted
CC       transmembrane domains varies between orthologs, but both N-
CC       terminus and C-terminus seem to be cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q92736-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q92736-2; Sequence=VSP_005953;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in heart muscle (at protein level).
CC       Heart muscle, brain (cerebellum and hippocampus) and placenta.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9607712}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in myometrium during pregnancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9148749}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By TGFB1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9148749}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- PTM: Channel activity is modulated by phosphorylation.
CC       Phosphorylation at Ser-2808 and Ser-2814 increases the open
CC       probability of the calcium channel. Phosphorylation is increased
CC       in failing heart, leading to calcium leaks and increased
CC       cytoplasmic Ca(2+) levels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056922}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-2031 by PKA enhances the response to
CC       lumenal calcium. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, familial, 2
CC       (ARVD2) [MIM:600996]: A congenital heart disease characterized by
CC       infiltration of adipose and fibrous tissue into the right
CC       ventricle and loss of myocardial cells, resulting in ventricular
CC       and supraventricular arrhythmias. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11159936}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Ventricular tachycardia, catecholaminergic polymorphic,
CC       1, with or without atrial dysfunction and/or dilated
CC       cardiomyopathy (CPVT1) [MIM:604772]: An arrhythmogenic disorder
CC       characterized by stress-induced, bidirectional ventricular
CC       tachycardia that may degenerate into cardiac arrest and cause
CC       sudden death. Patients present with recurrent syncope, seizures,
CC       or sudden death after physical activity or emotional stress. CPVT1
CC       inheritance is autosomal dominant. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11157710,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11208676, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12093772,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12106942, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14571276,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15046072, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15046073,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15466642, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15544015,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16188589, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17984046,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24793461, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25372681,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27733687}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.
CC       RYR2 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAH71369.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAH71393.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAH73918.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI14440.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI15350.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI15936.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI22065.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [11]
RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT MET-1, AND IDENTIFICATION BY
RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22223895; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M111.015131;
RA   Bienvenut W.V., Sumpton D., Martinez A., Lilla S., Espagne C.,
RA   Meinnel T., Giglione C.;
RT   "Comparative large-scale characterisation of plant vs. mammal proteins
RT   reveals similar and idiosyncratic N-alpha acetylation features.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 11:M111.015131-M111.015131(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a voltage-gated inward-rectifying Ca(2+)
CC       channel (VDCC) across the vacuole membrane. Is one of the
CC       essential components of the slow vacuolar (SV) channel. Acts as
CC       the major ROS-responsive Ca(2+) channel and is the possible target
CC       of Al-dependent inhibition. Involved in the regulation of
CC       germination and stomatal movement. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15464979,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772667}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Al(3+).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1552909, EBI-1552909;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772667, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17151019}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772667}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitously expressed.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11577183}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two internal repeats contains five hydrophobic
CC       transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one positively
CC       charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments probably represent
CC       the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a series of positively
CC       charged amino acids (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Plants display an impairment of both the
CC       Ca(2+) inhibition of stomatal guard cell opening and abscisic acid
CC       (ABA) inhibition of seed germination.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772667}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. Two pore calcium channel subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAD11598.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAD15312.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAB77841.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORM A).
RC   STRAIN=Berkeley {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAL25424.1};
RC   TISSUE=Embryo {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569};
RX   PubMed=12537569; DOI=10.1186/gb-2002-3-12-research0080;
RA   Stapleton M., Carlson J.W., Brokstein P., Yu C., Champe M.,
RA   George R.A., Guarin H., Kronmiller B., Pacleb J.M., Park S., Wan K.H.,
RA   Rubin G.M., Celniker S.E.;
RT   "A Drosophila full-length cDNA resource.";
RL   Genome Biol. 3:RESEARCH0080.1-RESEARCH0080.8(2002).
RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, ALTERNATIVE SPLICING, TISSUE
RP   SPECIFICITY, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND MUTAGENESIS OF GLU-79 AND
RP   GLY-128.
RX   PubMed=19737521; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2009.06.033;
RA   Yao C.-K., Lin Y.Q., Ly C.V., Ohyama T., Haueter C.M.,
RA   Moiseenkova-Bell V.Y., Wensel T.G., Bellen H.J.;
RT   "A synaptic vesicle-associated Ca2+ channel promotes endocytosis and
RT   couples exocytosis to endocytosis.";
RL   Cell 138:947-960(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: A calcium channel that regulates synaptic endocytosis
CC       and hence couples exo- with endocytosis. Isoform A and isoform B
CC       are mainly required in the nervous system and necessary in
CC       photoreceptor cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homomultimer; Isoform B. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-169467, EBI-169467;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasmic vesicle, secretory vesicle,
CC       synaptic vesicle membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}. Note=Upon
CC       fusion of the synaptic vesicle with the presynaptic membrane,
CC       protein is present in the periactive zones, where endocytosis is
CC       known to occur. {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=A {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521};
CC         IsoId=Q95T12-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521};
CC         IsoId=Q95T12-2; Sequence=VSP_053166;
CC       Name=C {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521};
CC         IsoId=Q95T12-3; Sequence=VSP_053165;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform B is expressed in the neuropils of
CC       embryonic, larval, adult CNS, and R1-R6 terminals. Expression in
CC       the central nervous system (CNS) starts at embryonic stage 13.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired intracellular resting calcium
CC       levels and impaired endocytosis in presynaptic terminals,
CC       exocytosis is normal. Mutant boutons at the neuromuscular
CC       junctions exhibit a significant depletion in the number of
CC       synaptic vesicles. There are numerous extra boutons which are
CC       often small, clustered, and flowery in nature. Mutant nerve
CC       terminals display omega structures and collared pits.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19737521}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel flower family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=28058752; DOI=10.1002/humu.23172;
RA   Boehm J., Bulla M., Urquhart J.E., Malfatti E., Williams S.G.,
RA   O'Sullivan J., Szlauer A., Koch C., Baranello G., Mora M.,

RT   "ORAI1 mutations with distinct channel gating defects in tubular
RT   aggregate myopathy.";
RL   Hum. Mutat. 38:426-438(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ca(2+) release-activated Ca(2+) (CRAC) channel subunit
CC       which mediates Ca(2+) influx following depletion of intracellular
CC       Ca(2+) stores and channel activation by the Ca(2+) sensor, STIM1
CC       (PubMed:16582901, PubMed:16645049, PubMed:16733527,
CC       PubMed:16766533, PubMed:16807233, PubMed:19249086,
CC       PubMed:23307288, PubMed:24351972, PubMed:24591628,
CC       PubMed:28219928). CRAC channels are the main pathway for Ca(2+)
CC       influx in T-cells and promote the immune response to pathogens by
CC       activating the transcription factor NFAT (PubMed:16582901).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16582901, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16645049,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16733527, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16766533,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16807233, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19249086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351972,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24591628, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28219928}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with STIM1 and STIM2; this regulates channel
CC       activity (PubMed:17905723, PubMed:19249086, PubMed:24351972,
CC       PubMed:28219928, PubMed:27185316). Interacts with CALM; this may
CC       displace STIM1 and STIM2 and might thereby modulate channel
CC       activity (PubMed:23109337). Interacts with CRACR2A/EFCAB4B; the
CC       interaction is direct and takes place in absence of Ca(2+)
CC       (PubMed:20418871). Forms a complex with CRACR2A/EFCAB4B and STIM1
CC       at low concentration of Ca(2+), the complex dissociates at
CC       elevated Ca(2+) concentrations. Interacts with ASPH (isoform 8)
CC       (PubMed:22586105). Interacts with SLC35G1 (PubMed:22084111).
CC       Interacts with UBQLN1 (PubMed:23307288).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17905723, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19249086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20418871, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22084111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22586105, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23109337,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351972,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28219928}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-2291476;
CC       O75185:ATP2C2; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-2939806;
CC       P62161:Calm3 (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-397530;
CC       Q9BSW2:CRACR2A; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-739773;
CC       Q9BRQ5:ORAI3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-4279484;
CC       Q13586:STIM1; NbExp=19; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-448878;
CC       P48995:TRPC1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-929665;
CC       Q13507:TRPC3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-520807;
CC       Q61143:Trpc6 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2291476, EBI-15563578;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16582901,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16645049, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19249086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22641696, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351972, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27185316,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28058752, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28219928}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16582901,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16645049, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19249086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22641696, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351972}.
CC       Note=Isoform beta is more mobile in the plasma membrane
CC       (PubMed:23307288). Colocalizes with STIM1 at the cell membrane
CC       (PubMed:27185316). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27185316}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative initiation; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=alpha;
CC         IsoId=Q96D31-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=beta;
CC         IsoId=Q96D31-2; Sequence=VSP_044421;
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19249086}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288}.
CC   -!- PTM: Cys-195 is oxidated, leading to inactivate channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28219928}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Immunodeficiency 9 (IMD9) [MIM:612782]: An immune
CC       disorder characterized by recurrent infections, impaired
CC       activation and proliferative response of T-cells, decreased T-cell
CC       production of cytokines, and normal lymphocytes counts and serum
CC       immunoglobulin levels. In surviving patients ectodermal dysplasia
CC       with anhidrosis and non-progressive myopathy may be observed.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16147976, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16582901}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myopathy, tubular aggregate, 2 (TAM2) [MIM:615883]: A
CC       rare congenital myopathy characterized by regular arrays of
CC       membrane tubules on muscle biopsies without additional
CC       histopathological hallmarks. Tubular aggregates in muscle are
CC       structures of variable appearance consisting of an outer tubule
CC       containing either one or more microtubule-like structures or
CC       amorphous material. TAM2 patients have myopathy and pupillary
CC       abnormalities. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24591628,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28058752}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: According to a report, ORAI1 has been shown to
CC       colocalize with UBQLN1 in the autophagosome as a target for
CC       autophagic degradation; ORAI1 is however not an autophagosomal
CC       protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23307288}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In Greek mythology, the 'Orai' are the keepers of
CC       the gates of heaven: Eunomia (order or harmony), Dike (justice)
CC       and Eirene (peace). {ECO:0000303|PubMed:16582901}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Orai family. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Progesterone activates the principal Ca2+ channel of human sperm.";
RL   Nature 471:387-391(2011).
RN   [9]
RP   ENZYME REGULATION.
RX   PubMed=26989199; DOI=10.1126/science.aad6887;
RA   Miller M.R., Mannowetz N., Iavarone A.T., Safavi R., Gracheva E.O.,
RA   Smith J.F., Hill R.Z., Bautista D.M., Kirichok Y., Lishko P.V.;
RT   "Unconventional endocannabinoid signaling governs sperm activation via
RT   sex hormone progesterone.";
RL   Science 352:555-559(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated calcium channel that plays a central role
CC       in calcium-dependent physiological responses essential for
CC       successful fertilization, such as sperm hyperactivation, acrosome
CC       reaction and chemotaxis towards the oocyte.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The CatSper calcium channel is indirectly
CC       activated by extracellular progesterone and prostaglandins
CC       following the sequence: progesterone > PGF1-alpha = PGE1 > PGA1 >
CC       PGE2 >> PGD2 (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339, PubMed:26989199).
CC       The CatSper calcium channel is directly inhibited by
CC       endocannabinoid 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2AG) (PubMed:26989199).
CC       Indirect activation by progesterone takes place via the following
CC       mechanism: progesterone binds and activates the acylglycerol
CC       lipase ABHD2, which in turn mediates hydrolysis of 2AG inhibitor,
CC       relieving inhibition of the CatSper channel (PubMed:26989199). The
CC       primary effect of progesterone activation is to shift voltage
CC       dependence towards more physiological, negative membrane
CC       potentials; it is not mediated by metabotropic receptors and
CC       second messengers (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339). Sperm
CC       capacitation enhances the effect of progesterone by providing
CC       additional negative shift. Also activated by the elevation of
CC       intracellular pH (PubMed:21412338, PubMed:21412339).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21412339,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26989199}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer; possibly composed of CATSPER1, CATSPER2,
CC       CATSPER3 and CATSPER4 (Potential). Component of the CatSper
CC       complex. Interacts with Ca(v)3.3/CACNA1I, leading to suppress T-
CC       type calcium channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16740636,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9P0X4:CACNA1I; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2215024, EBI-1220829;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium, flagellum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Specifically located in the principal piece of sperm tail.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Variant 2;
CC         IsoId=Q96P56-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Variant 1;
CC         IsoId=Q96P56-2; Sequence=VSP_026976;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Variant 3;
CC         IsoId=Q96P56-3; Sequence=VSP_026975, VSP_026977;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q96P56-4; Sequence=VSP_026973, VSP_026974;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11675491,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347248}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Deafness-infertility syndrome (DIS) [MIM:611102]:
CC       Characterized by deafness and infertility and is caused by large
CC       contiguous gene deletions at 15q15.3 that removes both STRC and
CC       CATSPER2 genes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12825070,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17098888}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation channel sperm-associated (TC
CC       1.A.1.19) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Structural component of the gap junctions and the
CC       hemichannels. May play a role as a Ca(2+)-leak channel to regulate
CC       ER Ca(2+) homeostasis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16908669,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20829356}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer. Forms homomeric or PANX1/PANX2-heteromeric
CC       intercellular channels on coexpression in paired Xenopus oocytes
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00351}. Cell
CC       junction, gap junction {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16908669,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17715132}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00351}.
