RX   PubMed=23942199; DOI=10.1038/ejhg.2013.178;
RA   Lainez S., Schlingmann K.P., van der Wijst J., Dworniczak B.,
RA   van Zeeland F., Konrad M., Bindels R.J., Hoenderop J.G.;
RT   "New TRPM6 missense mutations linked to hypomagnesemia with secondary
RT   hypocalcemia.";
RL   Eur. J. Hum. Genet. 22:497-504(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential ion channel and serine/threonine-protein
CC       kinase. Crucial for magnesium homeostasis. Has an important role
CC       in epithelial magnesium transport and in the active magnesium
CC       absorption in the gut and kidney. Isoforms of the type M6-kinase
CC       lack the ion channel region.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heterodimers with TRPM7. TRPM6 requires the
CC       presence of TRPM7 to be targeted to the cell membrane (in HEK 293
CC       cells). Interacts (via kinase domain) with RACK1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14976260, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18258429}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23942199};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=7;
CC       Name=TRPM6a;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=TRPM6b;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-2; Sequence=VSP_012069;
CC       Name=TRPM6c;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-3; Sequence=VSP_012070;
CC       Name=TRPM6t;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-4; Sequence=VSP_012075, VSP_012076;
CC       Name=M6-kinase 1;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-5; Sequence=VSP_012074;
CC         Note=Lacks the ion channel region.;
CC       Name=M6-kinase 2;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-6; Sequence=VSP_012073;
CC         Note=Lacks the ion channel region.;
CC       Name=M6-kinase 3;
CC         IsoId=Q9BX84-7; Sequence=VSP_012071, VSP_012072;
CC         Note=Lacks the ion channel region.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in kidney and colon. Isoform
CC       TRPM6a and isoform TRPM6b, are coexpressed with TRPM7 in kidney,
CC       and testis, and are also found in several cell lines of lung
CC       origin. Isoform TRPM6c is detected only in testis and in NCI-H510A
CC       small cell lung carcinoma cells.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Hypomagnesemia 1 (HOMG1) [MIM:602014]: A disorder due to
CC       a primary defect in intestinal magnesium absorption. It is
CC       characterized by low levels of serum magnesium alongside with a
CC       normal renal magnesium secretion, secondary hypocalcemia and
CC       calcinocis. Affected individuals show neurologic symptoms of
CC       hypomagnesemic hypocalcemia, including seizures and muscle spasms,
CC       during infancy. Hypocalcemia is secondary to parathyroid failure
CC       resulting from magnesium deficiency. Untreated, the disorder may
CC       be fatal or may result in neurological damage.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032568, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14976260,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23942199}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the protein
CC       kinase superfamily. Alpha-type protein kinase family. ALPK
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the transient
CC       receptor (TC 1.A.4) family. LTrpC subfamily. TRPM6 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane calcium uniporter that
CC       mediates calcium uptake into mitochondria. Constitutes a pore-
CC       forming and calcium-conducting subunit. Mitochondrial calcium
CC       homeostasis plays key roles in cellular physiology and regulates
CC       cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium signals and activation of
CC       cell death pathways. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8NE86}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MCU (TC 1.A.77) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH TCAF1 AND TCAF2.
RX   PubMed=25559186; DOI=10.1083/jcb.201402076;
RA   Gkika D., Lemonnier L., Shapovalov G., Gordienko D., Poux C.,
RA   Bernardini M., Bokhobza A., Bidaux G., Degerny C., Verreman K.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium selective cation channel that mediates Ca(2+)
CC       uptake in various tissues, including the intestine
CC       (PubMed:11097838, PubMed:11278579, PubMed:11248124
CC       PubMed:15184369, PubMed:23612980). Important for normal Ca(2+) ion
CC       homeostasis in the body, including bone and skin (By similarity).
CC       The channel is activated by low internal calcium level, probably
CC       including intracellular calcium store depletion, and the current
CC       exhibits an inward rectification (PubMed:15184369). Inactivation
CC       includes both a rapid Ca(2+)-dependent and a slower Ca(2+)-
CC       calmodulin-dependent mechanism; the latter may be regulated by
CC       phosphorylation. In vitro, is slowly inhibited by Mg(2+) in a
CC       voltage-independent manner. Heteromeric assembly with TRPV5 seems
CC       to modify channel properties. TRPV5-TRPV6 heteromultimeric
CC       concatemers exhibit voltage-dependent gating.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11097838,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248124, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278579,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184369, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23612980}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer and probably heterotetramer with TRPV5.
CC       Interacts with TRPV5. Interacts with S100A10 and probably with the
CC       ANAX2-S100A10 heterotetramer. The interaction with S100A10 is
CC       required for the trafficking to the plasma membrane. Interacts
CC       with BSPRY (By similarity). Interacts with TCAF1 and TCAF2 isoform
CC       2 (PubMed:25559186). Interacts with calmodulin (PubMed:11248124).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248124,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25559186}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P18031:PTPN1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-7198335, EBI-968788;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11097838,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248124, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278579,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184369, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23612980}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9H1D0-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9H1D0-2; Sequence=VSP_013439;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed at high levels in the
CC       gastrointestinal tract, including esophagus, stomach, duodenum,
CC       jejunum, ileum and colon, and in pancreas, placenta, prostate and
CC       salivary gland. Expressed at moderate levels in liver, kidney and
CC       testis. Expressed in trophoblasts of placenta villus trees (at
CC       protein level)(PubMed:23612980). Expressed in locally advanced
CC       prostate cancer, metastatic and androgen-insensitive prostatic
CC       lesions but not detected in healthy prostate tissue and benign
CC       prostatic hyperplasia. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11097838,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278579, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23612980}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23612980}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Tyr-201 by SRC leads to an increased
CC       calcium influx through the channel. Probably dephosphorylated at
CC       this site by PTPN1 (By similarity). Phosphorylation by PRKCA at
CC       the calmodulin binding site delays channel inactivation
CC       (PubMed:11248124). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9R186,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248124}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       TrpV subfamily. TRPV6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-selective calcium permeant cation channel involved
CC       in osmotic sensitivity and mechanosensitivity. Activation by
CC       exposure to hypotonicity within the physiological range exhibits
CC       an outward rectification (PubMed:18826956, PubMed:18695040). Also
CC       activated by heat, low pH, citrate and phorbol esters
CC       (PubMed:18826956, PubMed:18695040). Increase of intracellular
CC       Ca(2+) potentiates currents. Channel activity seems to be
CC       regulated by a calmodulin-dependent mechanism with a negative
CC       feedback mechanism (PubMed:12724311, PubMed:18826956). Promotes
CC       cell-cell junction formation in skin keratinocytes and plays an
CC       important role in the formation and/or maintenance of functional
CC       intercellular barriers (By similarity). Acts as a regulator of
CC       intracellular Ca(2+) in synoviocytes (PubMed:19759329). Plays an
CC       obligatory role as a molecular component in the nonselective
CC       cation channel activation induced by 4-alpha-phorbol 12,13-
CC       didecanoate and hypotonic stimulation in synoviocytes and also
CC       regulates production of IL-8 (PubMed:19759329). Together with
CC       PKD2, forms mechano- and thermosensitive channels in cilium
CC       (PubMed:18695040). Negatively regulates expression of PPARGC1A,
CC       UCP1, oxidative metabolism and respiration in adipocytes (By
CC       similarity). Regulates expression of chemokines and cytokines
CC       related to proinflammatory pathway in adipocytes (By similarity).
CC       Together with AQP5, controls regulatory volume decrease in
CC       salivary epithelial cells (By similarity). Required for normal
CC       development and maintenance of bone and cartilage
CC       (PubMed:26249260). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9EPK8,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11025659, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12724311,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18826956,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19759329, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26249260}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (Probable). Self-associates in a isoform-
CC       specific manner (PubMed:16293632). Isoforms 1/A and 5/D but not
CC       isoform 2/B, 4/C and 6/E can oligomerize (PubMed:16293632).
CC       Interacts with calmodulin (PubMed:12724311). Interacts with Map7
CC       and Src family Tyr protein kinases LYN, SRC, FYN, HCK, LCK and YES
CC       (By similarity). Interacts with CTNNB1 (By similarity). The TRPV4
CC       and CTNNB1 complex can interact with CDH1 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with PACSIN1, PACSIN2 and PACSIN3 (via SH3 domain) (By
CC       similarity). Part of a complex containing MLC1, AQP4, HEPACAM and
CC       ATP1B1 (PubMed:22328087). Interacts with ITPR3 (PubMed:18826956).
CC       Interacts with AQP5; the interaction is probably indirect and
CC       regulates TRPV4 activation by hypotonicity (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with ANO1 (By similarity). Interacts (via C-terminus)
CC       with PKD2 (via C-terminus) (PubMed:18695040).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9EPK8, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12724311,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16293632, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18826956, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22328087,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22702953, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-962786, EBI-962786;
CC       A0A0G2K4I1:Aqp4 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-962786, EBI-15907702;
CC       P47863-1:Aqp4 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-962786, EBI-15907676;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18826956}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein. Cell junction, adherens junction
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9EPK8}. Cell projection, cilium
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040}. Note=Assembly of the putative
CC       homotetramer occurs primarily in the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16293632, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037587,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037588}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Cell membrane.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 5: Cell membrane.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=B, OTRPC4beta;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-2; Sequence=VSP_013436;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=TRPV-SV;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-3; Sequence=VSP_013437;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=C;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-4; Sequence=VSP_026615;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=D;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-5; Sequence=VSP_026614;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=E;
CC         IsoId=Q9HBA0-6; Sequence=VSP_026615, VSP_013436;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Found in the synoviocytes from patients with
CC       (RA) and without (CTR) rheumatoid arthritis (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19759329}.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Genetic variations in TRPV4 determine the sodium
CC       serum level quantitative trait locus 1 (SSQTL1) [MIM:613508]. In
CC       some populations, variant Pro19Ser has been shown to be
CC       significantly associated with hyponatremia defined as serum sodium
CC       concentration below or equal to 135 mEq/L.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Brachyolmia 3 (BCYM3) [MIM:113500]: A form of
CC       brachyolmia, a clinically and genetically heterogeneous skeletal
CC       dysplasia primarily affecting the spine and characterized by a
CC       short trunk, short stature, and platyspondyly. BCYM3 is an
CC       autosomal dominant form with severe scoliosis with or without
CC       kyphosis, and flattened irregular cervical vertebrae.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18587396}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spondylometaphyseal dysplasia Kozlowski type (SMDK)
CC       [MIM:184252]: A form of spondylometaphyseal dysplasia, a group of
CC       short stature disorders distinguished by abnormalities in the
CC       vertebrae and the metaphyses of the tubular bones. It is
CC       characterized by postnatal dwarfism, significant scoliosis and
CC       mild metaphyseal abnormalities in the pelvis. The vertebrae
CC       exhibit platyspondyly and overfaced pedicles.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19232556, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20577006}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Metatropic dysplasia (MTD) [MIM:156530]: A severe
CC       spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia characterized by short limbs with
CC       limitation and enlargement of joints and usually severe
CC       kyphoscoliosis. Radiologic features include severe platyspondyly,
CC       severe metaphyseal enlargement and shortening of long bones.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19232556, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20425821,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20577006, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26249260,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.6}. Note=The disease is caused by mutations
CC       affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Neuronopathy, distal hereditary motor, 8 (HMN8)
CC       [MIM:600175]: A clinically variable, neuromuscular disorder
CC       characterized by congenital lower motor neuron disorder restricted
CC       to the lower part of the body. Clinical manifestations include
CC       non-progressive muscular atrophy, thigh muscle atrophy, weak thigh
CC       adductors, weak knee and foot extensors, minimal jaw muscle and
CC       neck flexor weakness, flexion contractures of knees and pes
CC       equinovarus. Tendon reflexes are normal.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037588, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22526352}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease 2C (CMT2C) [MIM:606071]: An
CC       axonal form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, a disorder of the
CC       peripheral nervous system, characterized by progressive weakness
CC       and atrophy, initially of the peroneal muscles and later of the
CC       distal muscles of the arms. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is
CC       classified in two main groups on the basis of electrophysiologic
CC       properties and histopathology: primary peripheral demyelinating
CC       neuropathies (designated CMT1 when they are dominantly inherited)
CC       and primary peripheral axonal neuropathies (CMT2). Neuropathies of
CC       the CMT2 group are characterized by signs of axonal degeneration
CC       in the absence of obvious myelin alterations, normal or slightly
CC       reduced nerve conduction velocities, and progressive distal muscle
CC       weakness and atrophy. Nerve conduction velocities are normal or
CC       slightly reduced. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037586,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037587, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037588,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21115951, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21288981}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Scapuloperoneal spinal muscular atrophy (SPSMA)
CC       [MIM:181405]: A clinically variable neuromuscular disorder
CC       characterized by neurogenic scapuloperoneal amyotrophy, laryngeal
CC       palsy, congenital absence of muscles, progressive scapuloperoneal
CC       atrophy and progressive distal weakness and amyotrophy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20037587}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia Maroteaux type (SEDM)
CC       [MIM:184095]: A clinically variable spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
CC       with manifestations limited to the musculoskeletal system.
CC       Clinical features include short stature, brachydactyly,
CC       platyspondyly, short and stubby hands and feet, epiphyseal
CC       hypoplasia of the large joints, and iliac hypoplasia. Intelligence
CC       is normal. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20503319}. Note=The disease is
CC       caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Parastremmatic dwarfism (PSTD) [MIM:168400]: A bone
CC       dysplasia characterized by severe dwarfism, kyphoscoliosis,
CC       distortion and bowing of the extremities, and contractures of the
CC       large joints. Radiographically, the disease is characterized by a
CC       combination of decreased bone density, bowing of the long bones,
CC       platyspondyly and striking irregularities of endochondral
CC       ossification with areas of calcific stippling and streaking in
CC       radiolucent epiphyses, metaphyses and apophyses.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20503319}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Digital arthropathy-brachydactyly, familial (FDAB)
CC       [MIM:606835]: A disorder characterized by irregularities in the
CC       proximal articular surfaces of the distal interphalangeal joints
CC       of the hand. Individuals appear normal at birth, with no clinical
CC       or radiographic evidence of a developmental skeletal dysplasia.
CC       The earliest changes appear during the first decade of life. By
CC       adulthood, all interphalangeal, metacarpophalangeal, and
CC       metatarsophalangeal joints are affected by a deforming, painful
CC       osteoarthritis. The remainder of the skeleton is clinically and
CC       radiographically unaffected. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21964574}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head, primary 2 (ANFH2)
CC       [MIM:617383]: A disease characterized by mechanical failure of the
CC       subchondral bone, and degeneration of the hip joint. It usually
CC       leads to destruction of the hip joint in the third to fifth decade
CC       of life. The clinical manifestations, such as pain on exertion, a
CC       limping gait, and a discrepancy in leg length, cause considerable
CC       disability. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27330106}. Note=The disease is
CC       caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       TrpV subfamily. TRPV4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Nagase T., Kikuno R., Nakayama M., Hirosawa M., Ohara O.;

RT   XVIII. The complete sequences of 100 new cDNA clones from brain which
RT   code for large proteins in vitro.";
RL   DNA Res. 7:273-281(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel mediating constitutive calcium ion
CC       entry. Its activity is increased by reduction in extracellular
CC       osmolarity, by store depletion and muscarinic receptor activation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672799, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=11;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=TRPM3f;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=TRPM3a;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-2; Sequence=VSP_012826;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=TRPM3b;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-3; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012828;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=TRPM3d;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-4; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012829;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=TRPM3e;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-5; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012828, VSP_012829;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=TRPM3c;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-6; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012830;
CC       Name=7;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-7; Sequence=VSP_012829;
CC       Name=8;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-8; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012827, VSP_012829;
CC       Name=10;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-10; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012831, VSP_012832;
CC       Name=11;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-11; Sequence=VSP_039107;
CC       Name=12;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-12; Sequence=VSP_043515, VSP_012826, VSP_043516;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed primarily in the kidney and, at
CC       lower levels, in brain, testis, ovary, pancreas and spinal cord.
CC       Expression in the brain and kidney was determined at protein
CC       level. In the kidney, expressed predominantly in the collecting
CC       tubular epithelium in the medulla, medullary rays, and
CC       periglomerular regions; in the brain, highest levels are found in
CC       the cerebellum, choroid plexus, the locus coeruleus, the posterior
CC       thalamus and the substantia nigra. Down-regulated in renal tumors
CC       compared to normal kidney. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672799,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       LTrpC subfamily. TRPM3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Structural component of the gap junctions and the
CC       hemichannels. May play a role as a Ca(2+)-leak channel to regulate
CC       ER Ca(2+) homeostasis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer. Forms homomeric or PANX1/PANX2-heteromeric
CC       intercellular channels on coexpression in paired Xenopus oocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P97382:Kcnab3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6272917, EBI-7261133;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00351}. Cell
CC       junction, gap junction. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00351}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed, including in cartilage,
CC       skin, spleen and brain.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylation may play a role in cell surface targeting.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17925379}.
CC   -!- PTM: S-nitrosylation inhibits channel currents and ATP release.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23033481}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the pannexin family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00351}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thought to stabilize the calcium channel in an
CC       inactivated (closed) state (By similarity). Modulates calcium
CC       current when coexpressed with CACNA1G. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10734232}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The L-type calcium channel is composed of five subunits:
CC       alpha-1, alpha-2/delta, beta and gamma. {ECO:0000250}.

CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.

CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH AP4M1 AND GRIA1, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF 227-TYR--THR-240.
RX   PubMed=18341993; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2008.02.012;
RA   Matsuda S., Miura E., Matsuda K., Kakegawa W., Kohda K., Watanabe M.,
RA   Yuzaki M.;
RT   "Accumulation of AMPA receptors in autophagosomes in neuronal axons
RT   lacking adaptor protein AP-4.";
RL   Neuron 57:730-745(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulates the trafficking to the somatodendritic
CC       compartment and gating properties of AMPA-selective glutamate
CC       receptors (AMPARs) (PubMed:18341993). Promotes their targeting to
CC       the cell membrane and synapses and modulates their gating
CC       properties by slowing their rates of activation, deactivation and
CC       desensitization. Does not show subunit-specific AMPA receptor
CC       regulation and regulates all AMPAR subunits. Thought to stabilize
CC       the calcium channel in an inactivated (closed) state (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8VHX0,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18341993}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The L-type calcium channel is composed of five subunits:
CC       alpha-1, alpha-2/delta, beta and gamma. Acts as an auxiliary
CC       subunit for AMPA-selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Found in
CC       a complex with GRIA1, GRIA2, GRIA3, GRIA4, CNIH2, CNIH3, CACNG2,
CC       CACNG4, CACNG5, CACNG7 and CACNG8 (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       AP4M1 and GRIA1; associates GRIA1 with the adaptor protein complex
CC       4 (AP-4) to target GRIA1 to the somatodendritic compartment of
CC       neurons (PubMed:18341993). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8VHX0,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18341993}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Note=Displays a somatodendritic
CC       localization and is excluded from axons in neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18341993}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PMP-22/EMP/MP20 family. CACNG
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   ERRATUM.
RX   PubMed=27559150; DOI=10.1124/mol.114.096511err;
RA   Azam L., Papakyriakou A., Zouridakis M., Giastas P., Tzartos S.J.,
RA   McIntosh J.M.;
RT   "Corrections to 'Molecular interaction of alpha-conotoxin RgIA with
RT   the rat alpha9alpha10 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor'.";
RL   Mol. Pharmacol. 90:415-417(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ionotropic receptor with a probable role in the
CC       modulation of auditory stimuli. Agonist binding may induce an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. The channel is permeable to a range of divalent cations
CC       including calcium, the influx of which may activate a potassium
CC       current which hyperpolarizes the cell membrane. In the ear, this
CC       leads to a reduction in basilar membrane motion, altering the
CC       activity of auditory nerve fibers and reducing the range of
CC       dynamic hearing. This may protect against acoustic trauma.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12117536,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14742688}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heterooligomeric channels in conjunction with
CC       CHRNA9. The native outer hair cell receptor may be composed of
CC       CHRNA9-CHRNA10 heterooligomers. Interacts with the conotoxin GeXXA
CC       (PubMed:26395518). Interacts with the alpha-conotoxin RgIA
CC       (PubMed:25740413). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25740413,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26395518}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the outer hair cells of the
CC       cochlea and the neurons of dorsal root ganglia.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12401316}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression in the inner hair cells of the ear
CC       is lost at the onset of hearing, around P12. This correlates with
CC       a loss of sensitivity of these cells to cholinergic stimuli.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15356192}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The heterooligomeric receptor composed of CHRNA9
CC       and CHRNA10 has an atypical pharmacological profile, binding
CC       several non-nicotinic ligands including strychnine (a glycine
CC       receptor antagonist) and atropine (a muscarinic acetylcholine
CC       receptor antagonist).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       10/CHRNA10 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=19133302; DOI=10.1016/j.bbamcr.2008.12.005;
RA   Giusti C., Tresse E., Luciani M.-F., Golstein P.;
RT   "Autophagic cell death: Analysis in Dictyostelium.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1793:1422-1431(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be a receptor for inositol 1,4,5 trisphosphate which
CC       governs calcium fluxes from the endoplasmic reticulum stores into
CC       the cytosol. May be involved in autophagic cell death.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12211100,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15760480, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17077123,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17854889, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18077554,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18196962, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19133302}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression is low during growth and rises to
CC       a peak at 9 hours of development when chemotactic aggregation to
CC       cyclic AMP is near its height; levels then decrease through the
CC       end of development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Null cells show abolition of calcium entry
CC       in response to chemoattractant, response to cyclic AMP and normal
CC       increase in free cytosolic calcium that follows chemotactic
CC       stimulation. Cells show formation of smaller fruiting bodies and
CC       abolition of autophagic cell death. Cells show absence of
CC       vacuolization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12211100, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15760480,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17077123, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18077554,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18196962, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19133302}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   GLYCOSYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ASN-386.
RC   TISSUE=Leukemic T-cell;
RX   PubMed=19349973; DOI=10.1038/nbt.1532;
RA   Wollscheid B., Bausch-Fluck D., Henderson C., O'Brien R., Bibel M.,
RA   Schiess R., Aebersold R., Watts J.D.;
RT   "Mass-spectrometric identification and relative quantification of N-
RT   linked cell surface glycoproteins.";
RL   Nat. Biotechnol. 27:378-386(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The alpha-2/delta subunit of voltage-dependent calcium
CC       channels regulates calcium current density and
CC       activation/inactivation kinetics of the calcium channel. Acts as a
CC       regulatory subunit for P/Q-type calcium channel (CACNA1A), N-type
CC       (CACNA1B), L-type (CACNA1C OR CACNA1D) and possibly T-type
CC       (CACNA1G). Overexpression induces apoptosis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12555074, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15111129}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer formed of alpha-2-2 and delta-2 chains; disulfide-
CC       linked. Voltage-dependent calcium channels are multisubunit
CC       complexes, consisting of alpha-1 (CACNA1), alpha-2 (CACNA2D), beta
CC       (CACNB) and delta (CACNA2D) subunits in a 1:1:1:1 ratio (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type I
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=Colocalizes with CACNA1A in
CC       lipid raft fractions. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2a;
CC         IsoId=Q9NY47-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2b;
CC         IsoId=Q9NY47-2; Sequence=VSP_028059;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9NY47-3; Sequence=VSP_028059, VSP_028060;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q9NY47-4; Sequence=VSP_028058, VSP_028059, VSP_028060;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=Alpha2delta-2c;
CC         IsoId=Q9NY47-5; Sequence=VSP_028060;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly present in cerebellar cortex.
CC       Present in various lung tumor cell lines, while it is absent in
CC       normal lung (at protein level). Highly expressed in heart, lung,
CC       testis, pancreas and skeletal muscle. Also expressed in kidney,
CC       liver, placenta and brain. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10766861,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11687876, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9880589}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The MIDAS-like motif in the VWFA domain binds divalent
CC       metal cations and is required to promote trafficking of the alpha-
CC       1 (CACNA1) subunit to the plasma membrane by an integrin-like
CC       switch. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: May be proteolytically processed into subunits alpha-2-2 and
CC       delta-2 that are disulfide-linked. It is however unclear whether
CC       such cleavage really takes place in vivo and has a functional role
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Binds gabapentin, an antiepileptic drug.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel subunit alpha-2/delta
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [20]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.8 ANGSTROMS) OF 699-743, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ASP-523 AND ASP-525.
RX   PubMed=23212381; DOI=10.1038/ncomms2257;
RA   Yu Y., Ulbrich M.H., Li M.H., Dobbins S., Zhang W.K., Tong L.,
RA   Isacoff E.Y., Yang J.;
RT   "Molecular mechanism of the assembly of an acid-sensing receptor ion
RT   channel complex.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 3:1252-1252(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming subunit of a ciliary calcium channel that
CC       controls calcium concentration within primary cilia without
CC       affecting cytoplasmic calcium concentration. Forms a heterodimer
CC       with PKD1L1 in primary cilia and forms a calcium-permeant ciliary
CC       channel that regulates sonic hedgehog/SHH signaling and GLI2
CC       transcription. May act as a sour taste receptor by forming a
CC       calcium channel with PKD1L3 in gustatory cells; however, its
CC       contribution to sour taste perception is unclear in vivo and may
CC       be indirect. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10517637,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19812697, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23212381,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The calcium channel is gated following an off-
CC       response property by acid: gated open after the removal of acid
CC       stimulus, but not during acid application.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18535624, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19464260,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22420714}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer; trimerization is independent of calcium-
CC       binding. Calcium channels are probably composed of 3 subunit of
CC       PKD2L1 and 1 subunit of some PKD1 protein (PKD1, PKD1L1, PKD1L2 or
CC       PKDL3). Interacts with PKD1. Interacts with PKD1L1; to form
CC       ciliary calcium channel. Interacts with PKD1L3, to form putative
CC       sour taste receptor. Interacts with RACK1; inhibits the channel
CC       activity possibly by impairing localization to the cell membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20408813, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20538909,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22174419, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22193359,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23212381, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24336289}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q8N6F1-2:CLDN19; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7956847, EBI-12256978;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum {ECO:0000250}. Note=Interaction with PKD1 or
CC       PKD1L3 is required for localization to the cell membrane.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0L9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=PKDLdel15, PCL-TS, Testis isoform;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0L9-2; Sequence=VSP_004730, VSP_004731;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=PKDLdel5;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0L9-3; Sequence=VSP_004729;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=PKDLdel456;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0L9-4; Sequence=VSP_004728;
CC         Note=Unusual intron exon spliced junction.;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=PCL-LV, Liver isoform;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0L9-5; Sequence=VSP_053718;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in adult heart, skeletal muscle,
CC       brain, spleen, testis, retina and liver. According to
CC       PubMed:9748274, expressed at high levels in fetal tissues,
CC       including kidney and liver, and down-regulated in adult tissues.
CC       According to PubMed:10602361, expressed in fetal brain, but not
CC       expressed in fetal lung, liver or kidney. Isoform 4 appears to be
CC       expressed only in transformed lymphoblasts.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10602361, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9748274}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EF-hand domain probably mediates calcium-binding. It
CC       is not required for channel activation (PubMed:11959145).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11959145}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: PKD1L3 and PKD2L1 have been defined as sour taste
CC       receptor in gustatory cells based on a number of indirect
CC       evidences in mouse. Some data confirm this hypothesis in human: in
CC       2 patients with sour ageusia that are unresponsive to sour
CC       stimuli, but show normal responses to bitter, sweet, and salty
CC       stimuli, expression of PKD1L3 and PKD2L1 is absent in the anterior
CC       part of the tongue (PubMed:19812697). However, a number of
CC       experiments have recently shown that the sour taste receptor
CC       activity is probably indirect. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19812697}.

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Leukemic T-cell;
RX   PubMed=19690332; DOI=10.1126/scisignal.2000007;
RA   Mayya V., Lundgren D.H., Hwang S.-I., Rezaul K., Wu L., Eng J.K.,
RA   Rodionov V., Han D.K.;
RT   "Quantitative phosphoproteomic analysis of T cell receptor signaling
RT   reveals system-wide modulation of protein-protein interactions.";
RL   Sci. Signal. 2:RA46-RA46(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) mediate the
CC       entry of calcium ions into excitable cells and are also involved
CC       in a variety of calcium-dependent processes, including muscle
CC       contraction, hormone or neurotransmitter release, gene expression,
CC       cell motility, cell division and cell death. This channel gives
CC       rise to T-type calcium currents. T-type calcium channels belong to
CC       the "low-voltage activated (LVA)" group and are strongly blocked
CC       by nickel and mibefradil. A particularity of this type of channels
CC       is an opening at quite negative potentials, and a voltage-
CC       dependent inactivation. T-type channels serve pacemaking functions
CC       in both central neurons and cardiac nodal cells and support
CC       calcium signaling in secretory cells and vascular smooth muscle.
CC       They may also be involved in the modulation of firing patterns of
CC       neurons which is important for information processing as well as
CC       in cell growth processes. Gates in voltage ranges similar to, but
CC       higher than alpha 1G or alpha 1H (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CATSPER1 and CATSPER2, leading to suppress
CC       T-type calcium channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16740636}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q8NEC5:CATSPER1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1220829, EBI-744545;
CC       Q96P56:CATSPER2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1220829, EBI-2215024;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Delta36b;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0X4-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0X4-2; Sequence=VSP_000951;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Alpha1I-a;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0X4-3; Sequence=VSP_000950, VSP_000951;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q9P0X4-4; Sequence=VSP_000950;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Brain specific.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the four internal repeats contains five
CC       hydrophobic transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one
CC       positively charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments
CC       probably represent the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a
CC       series of positively charged amino acids at every third position.
CC   -!- PTM: In response to raising of intracellular calcium, the T-type
CC       channels are activated by CaM-kinase II. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. CACNA1I subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

DE            Short=TrpV6;
DE   AltName: Full=Calcium transport protein 1 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:10428857};
DE            Short=CaT1 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:11287959};

RA   Brown E.M., Hediger M.A.;
RT   "Molecular cloning and characterization of a channel-like transporter
RT   mediating intestinal calcium absorption.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 274:22739-22746(1999).

RA   Sternfeld L., Anderie I., Schmid A., Al-Shaldi H., Krause E., Magg T.,
RA   Schreiner D., Hofer H.W., Schulz I.;

RT   Ca2+ channel TRPV6.";

RN   [4]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.25 ANGSTROMS) OF 41-709, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TOPOLOGY, AND REPEATS.
RX   PubMed=27296226; DOI=10.1038/nature17975;
RA   Saotome K., Singh A.K., Yelshanskaya M.V., Sobolevsky A.I.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the epithelial calcium channel TRPV6.";
RL   Nature 534:506-511(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium selective cation channel that mediates Ca(2+)
CC       uptake in various tissues, including the intestine
CC       (PubMed:10428857, PubMed:11287959, PubMed:27296226). Important for
CC       normal Ca(2+) ion homeostasis in the body, including bone and skin
CC       (By similarity). The channel is activated by low internal calcium
CC       level, probably including intracellular calcium store depletion,
CC       and the current exhibits an inward rectification (PubMed:10428857,
CC       PubMed:11287959, PubMed:27296226). Inactivation includes both a
CC       rapid Ca(2+)-dependent and a slower Ca(2+)-calmodulin-dependent
CC       mechanism; the latter may be regulated by phosphorylation. In
CC       vitro, is slowly inhibited by Mg(2+) in a voltage-independent
CC       manner. Heteromeric assembly with TRPV5 seems to modify channel
CC       properties. TRPV5-TRPV6 heteromultimeric concatemers exhibit
CC       voltage-dependent gating (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H1D0,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10428857, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287959,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27296226}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:27296226). Probably forms also
CC       heterotetramers with TRPV5. Interacts with TRPV5. Interacts with
CC       S100A10 and probably with the ANAX2-S100A10 heterotetramer. The
CC       interaction with S100A10 is required for the trafficking to the
CC       plasma membrane. Interacts with calmodulin. Interacts with BSPRY.
CC       Interacts with TCAF1 and TCAF2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H1D0, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27296226}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7198720, EBI-7198720;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10428857,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17197020, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27296226}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27296226}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in duodenum, proximal jejunum,
CC       cecum, and colon. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10428857}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H1D0}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Tyr-201 and Tyr-202 by SRC leads to an
CC       increased calcium influx through the channel. Probably
CC       dephosphorylated at these sites by PTPN1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17197020}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       TrpV subfamily. TRPV6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1 or Met-41 is the initiator.
CC       In human and mouse, initiation starts at a conserved non-canonical
CC       ACG threonine codon decoded as Met-1 upstream of the canonical
CC       initiation at Met-41. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q91WD2,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H1D0}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAD47636.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Unusual initiator. The initiator methionine is coded by a non-canonical ACG threonine codon.; Evidence={ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H1D0};

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RA   Birnbaumer L.;
RT   "Mouse trp2, the homologue of the human trpc2 pseudogene, encodes

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.

RA   Leypold B.G., Yu C.R., Leinders-Zufall T., Kim M.M., Zufall F.,
RA   Axel R.;
RT   "Altered sexual and social behaviors in trp2 mutant mice.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:6376-6381(2002).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=11823606; DOI=10.1126/science.1069259;
RA   Stowers L., Holy T.E., Meister M., Dulac C., Koentges G.;
RT   "Loss of sex discrimination and male-male aggression in mice deficient
RT   for TRP2.";
RL   Science 295:1493-1500(2002).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=20596023; DOI=10.1038/nature09142;
RA   Haga S., Hattori T., Sato T., Sato K., Matsuda S., Kobayakawa R.,
RA   Sakano H., Yoshihara Y., Kikusui T., Touhara K.;
RT   "The male mouse pheromone ESP1 enhances female sexual receptive
RT   behaviour through a specific vomeronasal receptor.";
RL   Nature 466:118-122(2010).
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=24089208; DOI=10.1038/nature12579;
RA   Ferrero D.M., Moeller L.M., Osakada T., Horio N., Li Q., Roy D.S.,
RA   Cichy A., Spehr M., Touhara K., Liberles S.D.;
RT   "A juvenile mouse pheromone inhibits sexual behaviour through the
RT   vomeronasal system.";
RL   Nature 502:368-371(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thought to form a receptor-activated non-selective
CC       calcium permeant cation channel. Probably is operated by a
CC       phosphatidylinositol second messenger system activated by receptor
CC       tyrosine kinases or G-protein coupled receptors. May also be
CC       activated by intracellular calcium store depletion. Plays a role
CC       in mediating responsivity to pheromones that elicit aggressive and
CC       mating behaviors. Required for response to the Esp1 pheromone
CC       which enhances female sexual receptive behavior and to the Esp22
CC       pheromone which inhibits adult male mating behavior.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11823606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11972034,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20596023, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24089208}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q9R244-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=B;
CC         IsoId=Q9R244-2; Sequence=VSP_006562;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Alpha;
CC         IsoId=Q9R244-3; Sequence=VSP_006564;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=Beta;
CC         IsoId=Q9R244-4; Sequence=VSP_006563, VSP_006565;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform 3 is ubiquitously expressed at low
CC       levels. Isoform 4 is expressed exclusively in vomeronasal organ.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Reduced electrophysiological response to
CC       pheromone mixtures in the vomeronasal organ. Mutant males and
CC       nursing females are docile and fail to initiate aggressive attacks
CC       on intruder males. Males display normal mating behavior towards
CC       females but display increased sexual behavior towards prepubescent
CC       females even when presented simultaneously with adult estrus
CC       females and also show increased sexual behavior towards juvenile
CC       and adult males. Lack of response to Esp1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11823606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11972034,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20596023, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24089208}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. TRPC2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=18713863; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0806015105;
RA   Jurynec M.J., Xia R., Mackrill J.J., Gunther D., Crawford T.,
RA   Flanigan K.M., Abramson J.J., Howard M.T., Grunwald D.J.;
RT   "Selenoprotein N is required for ryanodine receptor calcium release
RT   channel activity in human and zebrafish muscle.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105:12485-12490(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel that mediates the release of Ca(2+) from
CC       the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm in muscle and
CC       thereby plays a role in triggering muscle contraction. May
CC       regulate Ca(2+) release by other calcium channels. Calcium channel
CC       that mediates Ca(2+)-induced Ca(2+) release from the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum in non-muscle cells. Plays a role in cellular calcium
CC       signaling. Contributes to cellular calcium ion homeostasis.
CC       Isoform 2 lacks a predicted transmembrane segment and does not
CC       form functional calcium channels by itself; however, it can form
CC       tetramers with isoforms that contain the full complement of
CC       transmembrane segments and modulate their activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12213830,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305876, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9614063}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Isoform 2 can form tetramers with isoform
CC       1. Heterotetramer with RYR2. Interacts with FKBP1A. Interacts with
CC       CALM. Interacts with SELENON (PubMed:18713863).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12213830,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18713863, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9614063}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9542578, EBI-9542578;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Microsome
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Sarcoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18713863}. Note=The number of predicted
CC       transmembrane domains varies between orthologs, but both N-
CC       terminus and C-terminus seem to be cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=AS-8a;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-2; Sequence=VSP_042306;
CC         Note=Lacks a predicted transmembrane segment and does not form
CC         functional calcium channels.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-3; Sequence=VSP_042305;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-4; Sequence=VSP_042307;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in skeletal muscle from young rabbits
CC       and in adult diaphragm muscle (at protein level). Detected in
CC       brain, especially in corpus striatum, thalamus and hippocampus.
CC       Detected in taenia coli, uterus, vas deferens, aorta, stomach,
CC       small intestine, heart, diaphragm and ureter. Isoform 2 is highly
CC       expressed in uterus and aorta, and at much lower levels in heart,
CC       brain and diaphragm. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1330694,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176801, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305876}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Ubiquitous in skeletal muscle in neonates and
CC       in 15 day old rabbits. In adult, detected in diaphragm muscle, and
CC       in a subset of skeletal muscles including digastricus,
CC       pterygoideus, tongue and masseter. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176801}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10358090}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open calcium-release channel with high
CC       affinity. At low concentrations, ryanodine maintains the channel
CC       in an open conformation. High ryanodine concentrations inhibit
CC       channel activity. Channel activity is regulated by calmodulin
CC       (CALM). The calcium release is activated by elevated cytoplasmic
CC       calcium levels in the micromolar range, by caffeine and adenine
CC       nucleotides, such as AMP and ATP. Inhibited by Mg(2+) and
CC       ruthenium red.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.
CC       RYR3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ca(2+) release-activated Ca(2+) (CRAC) channel subunit

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21172611; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2010.11.026;
RA   Kato A.S., Gill M.B., Ho M.T., Yu H., Tu Y., Siuda E.R., Wang H.,
RA   Qian Y.W., Nisenbaum E.S., Tomita S., Bredt D.S.;
RT   "Hippocampal AMPA receptor gating controlled by both TARP and
RT   cornichon proteins.";
RL   Neuron 68:1082-1096(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulates the trafficking and gating properties of AMPA-
CC       selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Promotes their targeting
CC       to the cell membrane and synapses and modulates their gating
CC       properties by slowing their rates of activation, deactivation and
CC       desensitization and by mediating their resensitization. Does not
CC       show subunit-specific AMPA receptor regulation and regulates all
CC       AMPAR subunits. Thought to stabilize the calcium channel in an
CC       inactivated (closed) state. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21172611}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The L-type calcium channel is composed of five subunits:
CC       alpha-1, alpha-2/delta, beta and gamma. Acts as an auxiliary
CC       subunit for AMPA-selective glutamate receptors (AMPARs). Found in
CC       a complex with GRIA1, GRIA2, GRIA3, GRIA4, CNIH2, CNIH3, CACNG2,
CC       CACNG3, CACNG5, CACNG7 and CACNG8 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PMP-22/EMP/MP20 family. CACNG
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] LYS-138.
RX   PubMed=16959974; DOI=10.1126/science.1133427;
RA   Sjoeblom T., Jones S., Wood L.D., Parsons D.W., Lin J., Barber T.D.,
RA   Mandelker D., Leary R.J., Ptak J., Silliman N., Szabo S.,
RA   Buckhaults P., Farrell C., Meeh P., Markowitz S.D., Willis J.,
RA   Dawson D., Willson J.K.V., Gazdar A.F., Hartigan J., Wu L., Liu C.,

RA   Vogelstein B., Kinzler K.W., Velculescu V.E.;
RT   "The consensus coding sequences of human breast and colorectal
RT   cancers.";
RL   Science 314:268-274(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Form a receptor-activated non-selective calcium permeant
CC       cation channel. Acts as a cell-cell contact-dependent endothelial
CC       calcium entry channel. Probably operated by a phosphatidylinositol
CC       second messenger system activated by receptor tyrosine kinases or
CC       G-protein coupled receptors. Mediates cation entry, with an
CC       enhanced permeability to barium over calcium. May also be
CC       activated by intracellular calcium store depletion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16144838, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19996314}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with TRPC4AP (By similarity). Homotetramer and
CC       heterotetramer with TRPC1 and/or TRPC5. Isoform alpha but not
CC       isoform beta associates with inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor
CC       (ITPR). Interacts with (via PDZ-binding domain) with
CC       SLC9A3R1/NHERF. Interacts with MX1 and RNF24. Interacts (via CIRB
CC       domain) with SESTD1 (via spectrin 1 repeat). Interacts with CDH5
CC       and CTNNB1. Interacts with SPTAN1 (via C-terminal spectrin
CC       repeats) and SPTBN5 (via C-terminus). Interacts (via protein 4.1-
CC       binding domain) with EPB41L2. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032305, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12154080,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15757897, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16254212,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17850865, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18048348,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19996314, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20164195}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20591:MX1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-929504, EBI-929476;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Note=Enhanced insertion
CC       into the cell membrane after activation of the EGF receptor.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=7;
CC       Name=Alpha;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=Beta;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-2; Sequence=VSP_006569;
CC       Name=Delta;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-3; Sequence=VSP_006568;
CC       Name=Gamma;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-4; Sequence=VSP_006567, VSP_006569;
CC       Name=Epsilon;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-5; Sequence=VSP_041262;
CC       Name=Zeta;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-6; Sequence=VSP_041439;
CC       Name=Eta;
CC         IsoId=Q9UBN4-7; Sequence=VSP_047747, VSP_047748;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Strongly expressed in placenta. Expressed at
CC       lower levels in heart, pancreas, kidney and brain. Expressed in
CC       endothelial cells. Isoform alpha was found to be the predominant
CC       isoform. Isoform beta was not found in pancreas and brain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19996314}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The protein 4.1-binding domain (654-685) is required for
CC       binding to EPB41L2 and channel activation.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calmodulin- and inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor-
CC       binding (CIRB) domain (695-724) is sufficient for the interaction
CC       with SESTD1.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The spectrin-binding domain (730-758) is required for
CC       binding to SPTAN1 and SPTBN5.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation modulates TRPC channel function by regulating
CC       the level of TRPC4 at the cell surface and by increasing the
CC       association with SLC9A3R1/NHERF. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16144838}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The interaction with spectrin is important in
CC       controlling the translocation of TRPC4 channels to the plasma
CC       membrane following EGF stimulation.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The cell membrane presentation, the calcium entry
CC       function and the interaction with junctional proteins (CTNNB1 and
CC       CDH5) are controlled by endothelial cell-cell contacts.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. TRPC4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.71 ANGSTROMS) OF 26-237, FUNCTION,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, DISULFIDE BOND, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=25282151; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.2900;
RA   Zouridakis M., Giastas P., Zarkadas E., Chroni-Tzartou D.,
RA   Bregestovski P., Tzartos S.J.;
RT   "Crystal structures of free and antagonist-bound states of human
RT   alpha9 nicotinic receptor extracellular domain.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 21:976-980(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ionotropic receptor with a probable role in the
CC       modulation of auditory stimuli. Agonist binding induces a
CC       conformation change that leads to the opening of an ion-conducting
CC       channel across the plasma membrane (PubMed:11752216,
CC       PubMed:25282151). The channel is permeable to a range of divalent
CC       cations including calcium, the influx of which may activate a
CC       potassium current which hyperpolarizes the cell membrane
CC       (PubMed:11752216, PubMed:25282151). In the ear, this may lead to a
CC       reduction in basilar membrane motion, altering the activity of
CC       auditory nerve fibers and reducing the range of dynamic hearing.
CC       This may protect against acoustic trauma. May also regulate
CC       keratinocyte adhesion (PubMed:11021840).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11021840, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Can form homo- or heterooligomeric channels in
CC       conjunction with CHRNA10 (PubMed:11752216). The native outer hair
CC       cell receptor may be composed of CHRNA9-CHRNA10 heterooligomers.
CC       Interacts with the alpha-conotoxon RgIA (PubMed:22774872).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22774872}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P60616:- (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9008641, EBI-16123259;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25282151}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in cochlea, keratinocytes, pituitary
CC       gland, B-cells and T-cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11021840,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15531379}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The heterooligomeric receptor composed of CHRNA9
CC       and CHRNA10 has an atypical pharmacological profile, binding
CC       several non-nicotinic ligands including strychnine (a glycine
CC       receptor antagonist) and atropine (a muscarinic acetylcholine
CC       receptor antagonist). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11752216}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       9/CHRNA9 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   de Ligt J., Willemsen M.H., van Bon B.W., Kleefstra T., Yntema H.G.,
RA   Kroes T., Vulto-van Silfhout A.T., Koolen D.A., de Vries P.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thought to form a receptor-activated non-selective
CC       calcium permeant cation channel. Probably is operated by a
CC       phosphatidylinositol second messenger system activated by receptor
CC       tyrosine kinases or G-protein coupled receptors. Has also been
CC       shown to be calcium-selective (By similarity). May also be
CC       activated by intracellular calcium store depletion. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16284075}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Calcium channel activity is enhanced by MYLK,
CC       that promotes its subcellular localization at the plasma membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16284075}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with TRPC4AP (By similarity). Homotetramer and
CC       heterotetramer with TRPC1 and/or TRPC4. Interacts with NHERF (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with MX1 and RNF24. Interacts (via C-
CC       terminus) with CABP1. Interacts with SESTD1 (via the spectrin 1
CC       repeat). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032305,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15757897, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15895247,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17850865, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20164195}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16284075};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16284075}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in brain with higher levels in fetal
CC       brain. Found in cerebellum and occipital pole.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9687496}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. TRPC5 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAADP)
CC       receptor that may function as one of the major voltage-gated
CC       Ca(2+) channels (VDCC) across the lysosomal and endosomal
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5239895, EBI-5239895;
CC       O00165:HAX1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-5239895, EBI-357001;
CC       Q8NHX9:TPCN2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-5239895, EBI-5239949;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Lysosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}. Endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19620632}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9ULQ1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9ULQ1-2; Sequence=VSP_023003, VSP_023004, VSP_023005;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9ULQ1-3; Sequence=VSP_041346;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highest expression found in the heart and
CC       kidney, and lowest expression found in the spleen.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10574461}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two internal repeats contains five hydrophobic
CC       transmembrane segments (S1, S2, S3, S5, S6) and one positively
CC       charged transmembrane segment (S4). S4 segments probably represent
CC       the voltage-sensor and are characterized by a series of positively
CC       charged amino acids at every third position (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the calcium channel alpha-1 subunit (TC
CC       1.A.1.11) family. Two pore calcium channel subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC       Sequence=BAA86483.2; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [20]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, SUBUNIT, TOPOLOGY, AND MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   ASP-140.
RX   PubMed=27212239; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2016.04.051;
RA   Wang Q.C., Zheng Q., Tan H., Zhang B., Li X., Yang Y., Yu J., Liu Y.,
RA   Chai H., Wang X., Sun Z., Wang J.Q., Zhu S., Wang F., Yang M., Guo C.,
RA   Wang H., Zheng Q., Li Y., Chen Q., Zhou A., Tang T.S.;
RT   "TMCO1 is an ER Ca(2+) load-activated Ca(2+) channel.";
RL   Cell 165:1454-1466(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-selective channel required to prevent calcium
CC       stores from overfilling, thereby playing a key role in calcium
CC       homeostasis (PubMed:27212239). In response to endoplasmic
CC       reticulum overloading, assembles into a homotetramer, forming a
CC       functional calcium-selective channel, regulating the calcium
CC       content in endoplasmic reticulum store (PubMed:27212239).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27212239}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer and homotetramer (PubMed:27212239). Homodimer
CC       under resting conditions; forms homotetramers following and
CC       endoplasmic reticulum calcium overload (PubMed:27212239).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27212239}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27212239}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27212239}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320}. Note=The first transmembrane region
CC       is required for localization to the endoplasmic reticulum
CC       (PubMed:27212239). A publication reported localization in
CC       cytoplasm and nucleus (PubMed:22714896). Nuclear localization is
CC       however in contradiction with two other reports (PubMed:10393320,
CC       PubMed:27212239). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22714896, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27212239}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9UM00-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9UM00-2; Sequence=VSP_019505;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed in adult and fetal tissues,
CC       with higher levels in thymus, prostate, testis and small intestine
CC       and lower levels in brain, placenta, lung and kidney
CC       (PubMed:10393320, PubMed:20018682). Present in most tissues in the
CC       eye, including the trabecular meshwork and retina (at protein
CC       level) (PubMed:22714896). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10393320,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20018682, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22714896}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Craniofacial dysmorphism, skeletal anomalies and mental
CC       retardation syndrome (CFSMR) [MIM:213980]: A disorder
CC       characterized by craniofacial and skeletal anomalies, associated
CC       with mental retardation. Typical craniofacial dysmorphism include
CC       brachycephaly, highly arched bushy eyebrows, synophrys, long
CC       eyelashes, low-set ears, microdontism of primary teeth, and
CC       generalized gingival hyperplasia, whereas Sprengel deformity of
CC       scapula, fusion of spine, rib abnormities, pectus excavatum, and
CC       pes planus represent skeletal anomalies.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20018682, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23320496,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24194475}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Glaucoma, primary open angle (POAG) [MIM:137760]: A
CC       complex and genetically heterogeneous ocular disorder
CC       characterized by a specific pattern of optic nerve and visual
CC       field defects. The angle of the anterior chamber of the eye is
CC       open, and usually the intraocular pressure is increased. However,
CC       glaucoma can occur at any intraocular pressure. The disease is
CC       generally asymptomatic until the late stages, by which time
CC       significant and irreversible optic nerve damage has already taken
CC       place. In some cases, POAG shows digenic inheritance involving
CC       mutations in CYP1B1 and MYOC genes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21532571,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22714896}. Note=Disease susceptibility is
CC       associated with variations affecting the gene represented in this
CC       entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMCO1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: A light-sensitive calcium channel that is required for
CC       inositide-mediated Ca(2+) entry in the retina during phospholipase
CC       C (PLC)-mediated phototransduction (By similarity). Forms a
CC       regulated cation channel when heteromultimerized with trpl.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10896160}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts preferentially with trpl and interacts to a
CC       lower extent with trp. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10896160}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in the rhabdomeres of
CC       photoreceptor cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10896160}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.65 ANGSTROMS) OF 75-321, AND ANK REPEATS.
RX   PubMed=16809337; DOI=10.1074/jbc.C600153200;
RA   Jin X., Touhey J., Gaudet R.;
RT   "Structure of the N-terminal ankyrin repeat domain of the TRPV2 ion
RT   channel.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 281:25006-25010(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-permeable, non-selective cation channel with an
CC       outward rectification. Seems to be regulated, at least in part, by
CC       growth factors, like IGF1, PDGF and morphogenetic
CC       neuropeptide/head activator. May transduce physical stimuli in
CC       mast cells. Activated by temperatures higher than 52 degrees
CC       Celsius; is not activated by vanilloids and acidic pH (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10201375,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249591}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (Probable). Interacts with a cAMP-dependent
CC       protein kinase type II regulatory subunit (PRKAR2A or PRKAR2B) and
CC       ACBD3. Interacts with SLC50A1; the interaction probably occurs
CC       intracellularly and depends on TRPV2 N-glycosylation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14991772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249591,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11689641, EBI-11689641;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Melanosome {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Translocates from the cytoplasm to the plasma membrane upon
CC       ligand stimulation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitously expressed. Expressed in dorsal
CC       root ganglia, trigeminal ganglia, spinal chord (Lissauer's tract,
CC       dorsal horn and dorsal columns) (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10201375, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249591}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14622291}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by PKA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249591}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       TrpV subfamily. TRPV2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BAA93435.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=758; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   AND LYS-897, CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS FSGS2 SER-109; GLN-112;
RP   SER-125; SER-143; GLN-175; LEU-218; ALA-395; ASP-757; PRO-780;
RP   CYS-895; LEU-895 AND LYS-897, VARIANT VAL-404, CHARACTERIZATION OF
RP   VARIANT VAL-404, FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=26892346; DOI=10.1681/ASN.2015030318;
RA   Riehle M., Buescher A.K., Gohlke B.O., Kassmann M.,
RA   Kolatsi-Joannou M., Braesen J.H., Nagel M., Becker J.U., Winyard P.,
RA   Hoyer P.F., Preissner R., Krautwurst D., Gollasch M., Weber S.,
RA   Harteneck C.;
RT   "TRPC6 G757D Loss-of-Function Mutation Associates with FSGS.";
RL   J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 27:2771-2783(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Thought to form a receptor-activated non-selective
CC       calcium permeant cation channel (PubMed:19936226,
CC       PubMed:23291369). Probably is operated by a phosphatidylinositol
CC       second messenger system activated by receptor tyrosine kinases or
CC       G-protein coupled receptors. Activated by diacylglycerol (DAG) in
CC       a membrane-delimited fashion, independently of protein kinase C
CC       (PubMed:26892346). Seems not to be activated by intracellular
CC       calcium store depletion. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19936226,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23291369, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26892346}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer; forms channel complex (PubMed:26892346).
CC       Interacts with MX1 and RNF24 (PubMed:15757897, PubMed:17850865).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15757897, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17850865,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26892346}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20591:MX1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-929362, EBI-929476;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23291369,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26892346}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9Y210-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9Y210-2; Sequence=VSP_006572;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9Y210-3; Sequence=VSP_006573;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed primarily in placenta, lung, spleen,
CC       ovary and small intestine. Expressed in podocytes and is a
CC       component of the glomerular slit diaphragm.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15924139}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by FYN, leading to an increase of TRPC6
CC       channel activity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q61143}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis 2 (FSGS2)
CC       [MIM:603965]: A renal pathology defined by the presence of
CC       segmental sclerosis in glomeruli and resulting in proteinuria,
CC       reduced glomerular filtration rate and progressive decline in
CC       renal function. Renal insufficiency often progresses to end-stage
CC       renal disease, a highly morbid state requiring either dialysis
CC       therapy or kidney transplantation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15879175,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15924139, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19458060,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19936226, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20798252,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21511817, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21734084,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22732337, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23014460,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23291369, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26892346}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       STrpC subfamily. TRPC6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
